Sec. 2-156. - Disposition of personal property. 
(a)  Declaration of unserviceability. The Director shall effectuate the sale of personal property owned by the county under the supervision of the Board of Commissioners when it is determined and certified by the Director and the head of the user department in charge of the property that the property has depreciated to the point of useless life or to the extent that it is advisable to dispose of said personal property and is therefore unserviceable. The Director shall determine whether a particular item or category of personal property can no longer be used advantageously by the County and has therefore become unserviceable after conferring with the head of the user department desiring to sell the property. The Board of Commissioners may establish criteria establishing unserviceability for categories of personal property which may become unserviceable on a regular, frequently recurring basis, and may delegate to the Director the determination of whether a particular commodity meets the criteria of unserviceability for its category. 
(b)  Disposition. No sales of unserviceable county personal property shall be made by the Director under this section where other provisions of law provide for such sales, but this section shall apply to the sale of unserviceable county personal property where no other provision of law is made. Unserviceable personal property may be sold by public sale, sealed bidding, spot bidding or any other means deemed most advantageous to the County under the particular circumstances as determined by the Director. A sale to a private person shall be for the highest net purchase price reasonably obtainable by the County. A sale to another unit of government shall be for a fair and reasonable purchase price that need not be as high as the purchase price obtainable from a private person. All sales for personal property items where the original unit purchase cost is $25,000.00 or less shall be approved by the Director. The Board of Commissioners shall approve sales for personal property where original unit cost exceeds $25,000.00. The Director shall remit the proceeds from the sale to the Chief Financial Officer for deposit into the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 2017-45, § 1, 6-6-17) 
DIVISION 10. - ELECTRONIC COMMERCE 

Sec. 2-157. - Electronic transmissions of information. 
Electronic commerce shall include but not limited to on-line supplier registration, acceptance of bids and proposals by electronic mail, electronic or virtual purchasing malls and catalogs, internet auctions and reverse auctions, notifications of solicitations and download capability and acceptance of electronic (digital) signatures. 
Notwithstanding any other provisions, this chapter applies to records generated, stored, processed, communicated, or used for any purpose by Clayton County for purchasing, acquisition, services, or disposition of personal property. This shall apply to all Clayton County contracts. 
The Chief Operating Officer or his/her designee is authorized to promulgate procedures to coordinate, create, implement, and facilitate the use of common approaches and technical infrastructure, as appropriate, to enhance the utilization of electronic commerce, electronic records, electronic signatures, and electronic security procedures by and for Clayton County for these purposes. 
The Chief Operating Officer shall be authorized to develop, implement, and facilitate procedures for the use of electronic records, electronic signatures, and security procedures for all other purposes and is authorized to promulgate methods, means, and standards for secure electronic procurement transactions. 
(Ord. No. 2017-45, § 1, 6-6-17) 
Sec. 2-158. - Electronic signatures and records. 
An electronic record satisfies any rule requiring a document to be in writing. An electronic signature satisfies any rule of law requiring a signature. Any electronic record is signed as a matter of law if it contains a secure electronic signature. 
An electronic signature is deemed to be secure if it is created by application of a security procedure that is commercially reasonable and provided the electronic signature can be verified. Further, it is considered secure if it can be linked to the electronic record to which it relates in a manner such that, if the record is changed, the electronic signature is invalidated. 
An electronic record is deemed to be secure if it is created by application of a security procedure that is commercially reasonable and agreed to by Clayton County. The electronic record will be deemed secure when it can be verified not to have been altered since a specified point in time. 
(Ord. No. 2017-45, § 1, 6-6-17) 
Sec. 2-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RECORDS MANAGEMENT PLAN[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Records Act, O.C.G.A. tit. 50, ch. 18, art. 5. 

Sec. 2-160. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to provide for the creation of a records management plan for use by all county elected offices, and all departments, boards and authorities under the jurisdiction of the board of commissioners. It is further the purpose of this article to consolidate all records management operations under the direction and control of the board of commissioners through the archives and records administrator. Records requiring retention for several years will be transferred to the county archives and record center for low-cost storage at the earliest possible date following creation. In furtherance of these purposes, this article is based upon the premises that: 
(1)  The records of the county are public property; 
(2)  All records contain information needed for varying lengths of time for conducting public business; 
(3)  Certain records are essential for varying lengths of time for continuity of government or for the protection of the rights and privileges of its citizens; 
(4)  Certain records are essential as documentary evidence of our heritage; and 
(5)  Implementation of the records management plan will reduce the cost and improve the efficiency of records-keeping, and provide maximum utilization of county resources in office space and filing equipment. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-161. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the term: 
Archives and records center means an establishment maintained by the county for the storage, processing, servicing, and security of public records that must be retained for varying periods of time, but need not be retained in county office equipment or office space. "Archives and records center" also means an establishment maintained by the county for the preservation of those records and other papers that have been determined by the county to have sufficient historical and other value to warrant their continued preservation by the county and that have been accepted by the archives and records administrator for retention. 
Court records means all documents, papers, letters, maps, books (except books formally organized in libraries), microfilm, magnetic tape, or other material, regardless of physical form or characteristics, made or received pursuant to law or ordinance or, in the necessary performance of any judicial function, created or received by an official of the superior court, state court, juvenile court, probate court, or magistrate court. "Court records" also includes records of the offices of any judge, clerk, prosecuting attorney, court reporter, or any employee of the court system. 
Director means any director of a county department under the jurisdiction of the board of commissioners. For purposes of abbreviation, "department director" shall also include members of all boards and authorities under the jurisdiction of the board of commissioners. 
Official means any elected official of the county. 
Records means all documents, papers, letters, maps, books (except books in formally organized libraries), microfilm, magnetic tape, or other material, regardless of physical form or characteristics, made or received pursuant to law or ordinance or in performance of functions by any official or director. 
Records management means the application of management techniques to the creation, utilization, maintenance, retention, preservation, and disposal of records undertaken to reduce costs and improve efficiency of recordkeeping. "Records management" includes management of filing and microfilming equipment and supplies, filing and information retrieval systems, files, correspondence, reports, and forms management, historical documentation, micrographics, retention programming, and vital records protection. 
Records series means documents having similar physical characteristics or relating to a similar function or activity that are filed in a unified arrangement. 
Retention schedule means a set of disposition instructions prescribing how long, where, and in what form a record series shall be kept. 
Vital records means any record vital to the resumption or continuation of operations, or both; to the re-creation of the legal and financial status of the county; or to the protection and fulfillment of obligations to the citizens of the county. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-162. - Creation of archives and records administrator position. 
The position of archives and records administrator is hereby created. The archives and records administrator shall administer a records management program under the direction of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-163. - Development of rules and regulations; approval of retention schedules. 
The board of commissioners shall develop and issue procedures, rules and regulations, with the guidance of the state records committee and the state department of archives and history, for economical and efficient management relating to the creation, utilization, maintenance, retention, preservation, and disposition of records. The board of commissioners shall have final review of all proposed records retention schedules before they are submitted to the state records committee for approval. Once approved, the records retention schedules shall be authoritative, shall be directive, and shall have the force and effect of law. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-164. - Adoption of statewide records retention schedules. 
The statewide common records retention schedules applicable for county governments, the courts and law enforcement agencies are hereby adopted by reference and made the common schedule of the county. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-165. - Archives and records center. 
The archives and records center is hereby established to be located at such a place or places as the board of commissioners may designate. All records not required for normal operations shall be either destroyed or transferred to the archives and records center; provided, however, no records shall be destroyed, altered or transferred except in accordance with an approved retention schedule and the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-166. - Archives and records administrator—Actions. 
The archives and records administrator shall act for the board of commissioners in matters of: 
(1)  Establishing and maintaining an active and continuing program for the economical, efficient, and effective management of records; 
(2)  Establishing standards for economical, efficient management relating to the creation, utilization, maintenance, retention, preservation, and disposition of records; 
(3)  Assisting the officials and directors in developing and implementing a program of records management; 
(4)  Implementing records management procedures and regulations approved by the board of commissioners; and 
(5)  Developing and supervising a county archives and record center. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-167. - Same—Duties. 
It shall be the duty of the archives and records administrator to: 
(1)  Direct the records management plan to achieve the efficient and economical management practices relating to the creation, maintenance, utilization, retention, preservation, and disposition of records; 
(2)  Assist in the scheduling of records, develop a records control schedule, and maintain the schedule on a current basis; 
(3)  Supervise implementation of records retention schedules; 
(4)  Supervise physical transfer of records from high-cost office space to a low-cost records center, or to an archival depository; 
(5)  Develop and supervise a program of training in records management for selected personnel; 
(6)  Develop and establish a county-wide micrographics program; 
(7)  Prepare and submit reports of status and progress of the records management program to the board of commissioners; 
(8)  Review, evaluate, and recommend a more efficient information management system that will simplify operations throughout all offices of the county; 
(9)  Recommend the selection and utilization of filing equipment and supplies; 
(10)  Conduct an annual audit, at the direction of the board of commissioners, of departments to ensure that they are operating according to the provisions of this article; and 
(11)  Prepare destruction forms on any records that have reached their maximum retention date; and receive approval from officials and directors prior to actual destruction. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-168. - Responsibilities of officials and directors. 
It shall be the responsibility of the officials and directors to: 
(1)  Cooperate fully with the board of commissioners and the archives and records administrator in complying with the provisions of the Georgia Records Act and this article; 
(2)  Cause to be made and to preserve records containing adequate and proper documentation of the organization, policies, decisions, procedures, and essential transactions of the office, and designed to furnish the information necessary to protect the legal and financial rights of the county and of persons directly affected by the officials' or directors' activities; 
(3)  Implement records management procedures and regulations issued by the board of commissioners; 
(4)  Develop and submit to the archives and records administrator through the board of commissioners, in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Georgia Records Act, a recommended retention/disposition schedule for each records series in his/her custody, taking into consideration the policy of maintaining, in high-cost office space and filing equipment only, those records required for normal operations of the office or department, and transferring records not required for normal operations to low-cost storage in the county archives and record center; and 
(5)  Establish necessary safeguards against the removal or loss of records and such further safeguards as may be recommended by the archives and records administrator. Such safeguards shall include notification to all officials and directors that county records are public property and, as such, constitute a record of public acts. Such records shall not be placed in the custody of private or semi-private individuals, and no records in the custody of an official or director are to be destroyed or otherwise alienated except in accordance with the provisions of the Georgia Records Act and this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
State Law reference— Georgia Records Act, O.C.G.A. tit. 50, ch. 18, art.5. 
Sec. 2-169. - Priority. 
Priority in the records management program shall be given to: 
(1)  Writing retention schedules based on the legal, fiscal, administrative, and historical needs of the record; 
(2)  Preserving records of historical value; and 
(3)  Upgrading the existing records-keeping systems or designating new ones to extract maximum use and efficiency from the county's resources. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Sec. 2-170. - Authority to determine records; treatment of confidential records. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to divest any official or director of the authority to determine the nature and form of records required in the administration of their offices or departments. Any records designated confidential by law shall be so treated by the archives and records administrator in the maintenance, storage, and disposition of such confidential records. These records shall be destroyed in such manner that they cannot be read, interpreted, or reconstructed. 
Sec. 2-171. - Title to, destruction of, access to records. 
Title to any record transferred to the archives and retention center as authorized by this article shall be vested and remain in the office or department of origination. The archives and records administrator shall not destroy any record transferred to him by an official or director without consulting with the proper personnel of the transferring office or department and receiving a retention schedule directive requesting such destruction. Access to the respective records of officials and directors shall be at the discretion of the official or the board of commissioners who created, received, or maintained the records. 
(Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 2-20-96) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; public consumption of alcoholic beverages prohibited, § 62-8; alcoholic beverages in parks, § 66-18; alcohol and substance abuse policy, § 70-126 et seq. 
State Law reference— Use of proceeds of alcoholic beverage tax for prevention, education and treatment, Ga. Const. art. 3, sec. 9, par. 6; Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; furnishing to, purchase of or possession by persons under 21 years of age, use of false identification, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41; furnishing alcoholic beverages to persons under 21 years of age, jurisdiction of municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-10; treatment of alcoholics and intoxicated persons, O.C.G.A. § 37-8-1 et seq.; driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-391. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Intent. 
The regulations in this chapter have been enacted in accordance with a plan designed for the purposes, among others, to: 
(1)  Promote the health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the county; 
(2)  Establish reasonable standards for the regulation and control of the licensing and sales of alcoholic beverages; 
(3)  Protect and preserve schools, churches and similar places of public assembly; and 
(4)  Give effect to existing land use plans and preserve residential areas regarding, among other things, the character of the areas, their peculiar suitability for particular uses and the congestion in the surrounding roads and streets, with a general view of promoting desirable living conditions and sustaining the stability of neighborhood and property values. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-1) 
Sec. 6-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of the ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. 
Alcoholic beverage means all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine, or fortified wine. 
Applicant means an individual applying for any license authorized by this chapter. 
Application means a form supplied by the county for the purpose of applying for any license authorized by this chapter. 
Church means a permanent building where persons regularly assemble for religious worship. 
Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume, including, but not limited to, whiskey, rum, gin, brandy, vodka, tequila and fortified wines. 
Family means any person related to a licensee within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as determined according to civil law. 
Fortified wine means any alcoholic beverage containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added, including but not limited to brandy. 
Hotel means any building or structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where a minimum of 50 sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests, and food is actually served and consumed in one or more dining rooms, having an adequate and sanitary kitchen and minimum seating capacity of 60, such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted on the same premises. 
Individual means a natural person. 
Interest in license means an interest held by an owner or co-owner of a license; a partner of a partnership which owns or co-owns a license; a stockholder in any corporation which owns or co-owns a license; an owner, co-owner, lessor, sublessor, partner in a partnership or stockholder in a corporation owning or leasing any real estate on which is located a retail consumption dealer, a retail dealer or wholesale dealer; or anyone sharing in the income or corpus of any trust or estate having such an interest. 
License means authorization granted by the county to operate as a retail consumption dealer, retail dealer or wholesale dealer. 
License department means the department of community development. 
Licensee means a person holding a license. 
Lounge means a separate room or area connected with, a part of or adjacent to a restaurant or located in a hotel or motel, said room having as a part of its functions the serving only of alcoholic beverages as distinguished from the serving of such beverages with meals. 
Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than six percent alcohol by volume, and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer and strong beer, but not including sake. 
Motel means any building or structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where a minimum of 50 sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests, and food is actually served and consumed in one or more dining rooms, having an adequate and sanitary kitchen and a minimum seating capacity of 60 such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted on the same premises. 
Package means a six-pack, keg, case, barrel or other original consumer container arrangement, but does not include single cans or bottles. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, fiduciary or other group or combination acting as a unit, body politic or political subdivision, whether public, private or quasipublic. 
Premises means the definite closed or partitioned-in locality, whether a room, shop or building. 
Private club means a corporation or association organized and existing under the laws of the state, actively in operation within the county at least eight years prior to the application for a license under this chapter, having at least 200 members regularly paying dues, for at least five years prior to application for license, organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation and other nonprofitable purposes, no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of the shareholder or member and owning, hiring or leasing a building or space therein for the reasonable use of its members with suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining and using a sufficient number of servants and employees for cooking, preparing and serving meals for its members and guests; provided that no member or officer, agent or employee of the club is paid, or directly or indirectly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of distilled spirits, wine or malt beverages beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its members at an annual meeting, or by its governing body, out of the general revenue of the club. For the purpose of this definition, tips which are added to the bills under club regulations shall not be considered as profits under this definition. A private club organized or operated primarily for the selling or serving of alcoholic beverages by the drink shall not be licensed under this chapter nor permitted to sell or serve such beverages at all. 
Private residence means a house, dwelling, condominium or duplex wherein not less than one nor more than two families reside; not including a mobile home, an apartment house having facilities for the housing of more than two families, a boardinghouse or roominghouse where there are five or more boarders, nor any residence located in a commercially or industrially zoned district. 
Restaurant means a food serving establishment for the preparation, serving, and consumption on the premises of meals, which may include breakfast, lunch, or dinner. The establishment, including diners, coffee shops, cafeterias, cafes, luncheonettes, lunchrooms, catering establishments, and similar facilities by whatever name called shall have adequate kitchen and dining equipment. Such establishments must have a minimum seating capacity of 50 in order to serve beer, wine and distilled spirits to be consumed on the premises. The term shall not mean a "food sales establishment," as defined in the O.C.G.A. § 26-2-21, and which does not provide seating or facilities for consumption of food on the premises. 
Retail consumption dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises at retail only to consumers and not for resale. 
Retail dealer means any person who sells malt beverages and/or wine in unbroken packages at retail only to consumers and not for resale or for consumption on the premises. 
Seating capacity means the amount of individual seating which is located at tables for the purpose of serving the dining public, but not including any seating located in a lounge, bar or other area designated primarily for the serving of alcoholic beverages. 
Sports club means an association or corporation organized and existing under the laws of the state, organized and operated primarily to provide a location for the patrons thereof to engage in sporting events. To qualify for an alcoholic beverage consumption dealer's license, a sports club must have been actively in operation within the county at least two years prior to an application for license under this chapter. Further, no member or officer, agent or employee of the club, directly or indirectly, shall be paid or shall receive in the form of salary or other compensation any profits from the sale of distilled spirits, wine or malt beverages beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its governing body out of the general revenue of the club. For the purpose of this definition, tips which are added to the bills shall not be considered as profits under this definition. Provided, however, the two-year operational requirement shall not apply to golf club associations or golf club corporations where the selling or serving of alcoholic beverages is to take place in a facility located on the golf course premises. A sports club organized or operated primarily for the selling or serving of alcoholic beverages by the drink shall not qualify for licensing under this chapter, and accordingly shall not be permitted to sell or serve alcoholic beverages at any time. Unless otherwise indicated, a sports club licensee shall otherwise comply with all other requirements imposed upon retail consumption dealers. 
Wholesale dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages to retail consumption dealers, retail dealers or other wholesale dealers for resale. 
Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added, including but not limited to sparkling wine, champagne, combinations of such beverages, vermouth, special natural wine, rectified wine and like products, but not including cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-2; Ord. No. 2004-154, § 1, 9-21-04; Ord. No. 2015-95, § 1, 4-21-15) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-3. - Construction of definitions. 
Words and terms not explicitly defined in this chapter shall have the meaning given by common and ordinary use as defined in the latest edition of Webster's New Collegiate Dictionary. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-3) 
Sec. 6-4. - License required. 
Any person desiring to operate in the county as a retail consumption dealer, retail dealer or wholesale dealer shall apply for and obtain a license from the county prior to commencing operations. Operating without a license shall be a violation of this chapter and punishable as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-4) 
Sec. 6-5. - License eligibility. 
(a)  No retail consumption license shall be issued to any applicant whose establishment does not meet the definition of a restaurant, hotel, motel, private club, or sports club as prescribed by this chapter. 
(b)  No retail dealer license shall be issued to any applicant whose business does not have at least a $15,000.00 inventory of food, tobacco products, household supplies and periodicals. Automotive supplies shall not be considered in determining inventory. 
(c)  No retail consumption license shall be issued to any applicant who operates a restaurant or a lounge in conjunction with a restaurant unless the restaurant or combined lounge/restaurant operation has as its principal business the serving of meals, which, excluding the sale of alcoholic beverages, account for at least 60 percent of the gross revenue of the business. Returns indicating average restaurant or combined lounge/restaurant revenue for three consecutive months preceding any audit date shall be considered for purpose of determining compliance with this section. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-5; Ord. No. 93-45, § I, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 2015-95, § 2, 4-21-15) 
Sec. 6-6. - License restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall hold a license to operate as a retail consumption dealer or retail dealer who also has an interest in a license to operate as a wholesale dealer. 
(b)  No elected or appointed official, employee or agent of the county, directly or indirectly, shall be a licensee. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-6; Ord. No. 93-37, § I, 4-20-93; Ord. No. 2016-178, § 1, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 6-7. - Business location. 
(a)  Licenses shall not be issued to authorize the sale of alcoholic beverages at any location which does not meet or exceed the following minimum distance separation requirements from the establishments set forth in this section. Provided, however, the minimum distance of separation specified herein shall be required only on the first license application as it relates to any one particular business location. 
(1)  For dealers of distilled spirits, the licensee's premises cannot be located within 100 yards of any church building or within 200 yards of any school or education building, school ground, publicly owned recreational ground or college campus. 
(2)  For dealers of wine or malt beverages, the licensee's premises cannot be located within 100 yards of any church building or within 100 yards of any school or educational building, school ground, publicly owned recreational ground, or college campus. 
(3)  For dealers of distilled spirits, wine or malt beverages, the licensee's premises cannot be located within 100 yards of any alcoholic treatment center. 
(b)  As used in this section, the terms "school," "educational building" or "college campus" shall apply only to state, county, city, church or private institutions at which are found curriculums frequently taught in the common schools and colleges of this state. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, all distances from the proposed licensed establishment to the applicable building, structure or grounds shall be measured by the most direct route of travel and shall be measured in the following manner: 
(1)  From the front door of the structure or partial building unit from which beverage alcohol is sold or offered for sale; thence, 
(2)  In a straight line, regardless of obstructions, to the nearest public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway; thence, 
(3)  Along such public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway by the nearest route; thence, 
(4)  To the front door of the building or to the nearest portion of the grounds, whichever is applicable. 
(d)  For the purposes of this section, the term "building" shall mean any nonaccessory structure located on the school ground, college campus or alcoholic treatment center which would not be considered an accessory use under the appropriate interpretations of the zoning ordinance of the county. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-7) 
Sec. 6-8. - Business entrance. 
The front entrance of all licensed premises shall be clearly visible from a public street; however, this restriction shall not apply where the premises are located in a hotel, motel, private club, shopping center or multiple-story business building. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-8) 
Sec. 6-9. - Open containers. 
(a)  Definition. As used in this section, "open container" means any container which is immediately capable of being consumed from or the seal of which has been broken. 
(b)  Possession prohibited. It is unlawful and punishable as provided in this section for any person to possess an open container of an alcoholic beverage while operating a vehicle in the county or while a passenger in or on a vehicle being operated in the county. 
(c)  Possession of operator. An open container shall be considered to be in the possession of the operator of a vehicle if the container is not in the possession of a passenger and is not located in a locked glove compartment, locked trunk or other locked nonpassenger area of the vehicle. 
(d)  Possession of passenger. An open container shall be considered to be in the possession of a passenger of a vehicle if the container is in the physical control of the passenger. 
(e)  Application of section. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  A passenger of a vehicle in which the driver is operating the vehicle pursuant to a contract to provide transportation for passengers and such driver holds a valid chauffeur's license pursuant to state law or any other state; 
(2)  A passenger of a bus in which the driver holds a valid chauffeur's license pursuant to state law or any other state; or 
(3)  A passenger of a self-contained motor home which is in excess of 21 feet in length. 
(f)  Penalty for violation. Any person, operator of a vehicle or passenger who violates this section shall be treated by the courts of this state in the same manner as misdemeanors and shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-9) 
Secs. 6-10—6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 6-31. - Periodic inspection. 
Sworn officers of the police department shall have the authority to inspect establishments licensed under this chapter during the hours in which the premises are open for business. The inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-101) 
Sec. 6-32. - Automatic revocation. 
Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to sell alcoholic beverages, the county license to deal in such products, issued pursuant to this chapter, shall thereupon be automatically revoked without any action by the board of commissioners or any other county officer being necessary. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-102) 
Sec. 6-33. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)  No license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued pursuant to this chapter shall be suspended or revoked, except for due cause as hereinafter defined. 
(b)  Suspensions and revocations of licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be conducted in the same manner and by the same method as provided in the general business license regulations of section 22-34. 
(c)  "Due cause" for the suspension or revocation of such license shall consist of the violation of any laws or ordinances regulating such businesses, or violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such businesses, or for the violation of any state or federal law, or for the violation of any county ordinances other than traffic ordinances, which in the opinion of the board of commissioners render the licensee improper to hold such license. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-103) 
Sec. 6-34. - Refunds. 
If a license issued under this chapter is suspended or revoked, the licensee shall not be entitled to a refund of any portion of the application, license or employee fees previously remitted. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-104) 
Secs. 6-35—6-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LICENSING GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-56. - Application required. 
(a)  Every person desiring to operate within the county as a retail consumption dealer or retail dealer shall make an application therefor. Such forms necessary for such application shall be furnished by the county. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable investigation fee of $250.00. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-11) 
Sec. 6-57. - Applicant. 
The applicant shall be the owner of the proposed business if the business is solely owned or the co-owner if a partnership or firm. If a proposed licensee is a corporation, the applicant may be the president, a vice-president, secretary or treasurer of the corporation or the corporation's general manager at the particular business location. Otherwise, no other individual may qualify as an applicant. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-12) 
Sec. 6-58. - Hotels, motels. 
Hotel and motel corporations and their franchise restaurant corporations operating as contemplated in this chapter are authorized to apply for and to hold a retail consumption license in their corporate names. They shall name on such application an agent and/or manager actively employed in the operation of such hotel, motel or franchise restaurant who shall be responsible for operation under such license and who shall qualify in all respects under these regulations. Should such manager and/or agent leave the employment of the hotel or motel corporation or its franchise restaurant corporation in the county, a new agent and/or manager shall be named by the licensee within ten days thereafter. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-13) 
Sec. 6-59. - Qualifications of applicants. 
(a)  The application shall list and, if issued, the licensee shall indicate the following as licensees: 
(1)  The business operation; 
(2)  The owner if the business is solely owned; 
(3)  Each co-owner if the business is a partnership or firm; and 
(4)  The general manager of the particular business location. 
(b)  Each individual licensee shall be a citizen of the United States or a permanent resident alien as defined by the Immigration and Nationality Laws of the United States. 
(c)  Each individual licensee shall have been and continue to be a resident of the state for the period of one year immediately preceding the date of application. Corporations, however, must either be incorporated in the state or must have registered to do business in this state. 
(d)  No licensee shall have been convicted nor entered a plea nolo contendere within ten years immediately preceding the date of application for any felony or crime involving moral turpitude. In those instances involving partnerships or corporations, this prohibition may also apply to partners of the licensee or officers and stockholders of a corporation, if in the opinion of the director of community development such person by virtue of their office or ownership position in the business would have a material influence in the operation of the business. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-14) 
Sec. 6-60. - Application contents. 
The application shall contain, under oath, the following information and documents: 
(1)  Name and address of each applicant and each person who would have a beneficial interest in the license; however, including only those stockholders owning five percent or more of the corporation's stock; 
(2)  Name and the address for the past ten years of each individual licensee, including registered agent where necessary; 
(3)  The name, address and date of birth of each employee working at the business location; 
(4)  Description of the business operation, its location and facilities; 
(5)  Blueprint or scale drawing of the business facilities; 
(6)  Survey indicating the location of the business and the distance to the nearest school, church and alcoholic treatment center, as described in section 6-7; and 
(7)  Such other information and documents as may be required by the department of community development. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-15) 
Sec. 6-61. - Licensing considerations. 
In determining whether or not any application shall be granted and a license issued, the department of community development shall consider the following information in the public interest and welfare: 
(1)  If the applicant and/or licensee has ever violated any federal, state, county or city law or regulation regarding alcoholic beverages, their sale, distribution or manufacture; 
(2)  The manner in which the applicant and/or licensee has conducted any business within the county as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance or as to the necessity for county action to compel the applicant's and/or licensee's adherence to any county law, regulation or ordinance; 
(3)  The location for which the license is sought as to traffic congestion, public safety, the general character of the neighborhood and the effect of such an operation on surrounding property values; and 
(4)  Whether the applicant and/or licensee has ever had an alcoholic beverage or business license suspended or revoked by the state or any political subdivision thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-16) 
Sec. 6-62. - Review of applications; administration of article. 
(a)  The license department shall review all applications for an alcoholic beverage license for compliance with these regulations. All applicants shall furnish upon request all data, information and records necessary for a complete investigation. 
(b)  The department of community development shall also have authority to prescribe such forms as it deems necessary for the proper administration of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-17) 
Sec. 6-63. - Misleading, omitted or obsolete information. 
(a)  Any untrue or misleading information contained in or material omission left out of an original or renewal application for an alcoholic beverage license shall be cause sufficient for the denial thereof. 
(b)  Any information which changes or otherwise becomes obsolete shall be reported immediately. 
(c)  When any license is issued on the basis of an application containing misleading or untrue information or omitted or unreported changed material information, such circumstances shall be cause for revocation of same. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-18) 
Sec. 6-64. - Grant of application. 
(a)  All applications for alcoholic beverage licenses meeting the provisions of this article shall be granted by the director of community development, unless some specific cause regarding location, traffic conditions or environmental conditions justify a refusal. In such event, the applicant shall be entitled to file a new application of like kind for a different location without the loss of any part of the application fee. 
(b)  If the director denies an application for a license, the applicant shall have the right to appeal such decision in the same manner and by the same method as provided in the general business license regulations of the county. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-19) 
Sec. 6-65. - License period; proration of fee. 
All licenses required by this article shall issue and be effective for the calendar year beginning January 1, and fees required by this article shall be paid in full before the issuance of the license. Applications for licenses to be issued after June 30th shall pay a license fee prorated on a semiannual basis. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-20) 
Sec. 6-66. - Transfers. 
(a)  Licenses granted under this article shall not be transferable, either by location or among persons, except as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  In the case of a death of any person having an interest in a license, the license may be transferred to the estate of the deceased person; however, an individual shall be named as responsible for such interest, and such individual shall be subject to the qualifications of an applicant and licensee. 
(c)  One or more partners in a partnership holding a license may withdraw in favor of one or more of the existing partners. In addition, a licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined that the additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or for the expansion of facilities and that the licensee himself is receiving none of the additional capital invested. All such additional partners or new principal stockholders must be approved by the department of community development. Otherwise, no new ownership may be allowed an interest in a license. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-21) 
Sec. 6-67. - Fees. 
(a)  The fee schedule for all alcoholic beverage licenses shall be as follows: 
(1)  Restaurant, retail consumption, $4,000.00. 
(2)  Restaurant, malt beverage and wine retail consumption, $4,000.00. 
(3)  Private clubs, retail consumption, or sports clubs, retail consumption, $1,000.00. 
(4)  Retail dealer, $4,000.00. 
(b)  All license fees shall be paid on or before November 15 for the following calendar year or within ten days of the grant of an application for a license. 
(c)  All license fees shall be paid in full regardless of when a license is granted. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-22; Ord. No. 93-37, § II, 4-20-93; Ord. No. 93-45, § II, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 99-103, § I, 9-21-99; Ord. No. 2016-178, § 2, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 6-68. - License authority. 
Licensees holding a retail consumption license shall have authority under such license to sell and serve distilled spirits, malt beverages and wine. Licensees holding a retail dealer license shall have authority under such license to sell only malt beverages and wine. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-23) 
Secs. 6-69—6-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WHOLESALE LICENSE 

Sec. 6-91. - Retail license provisions. 
All provisions pertaining to application for licenses described in article III shall apply with equal force to wholesale licenses except as modified herein, provided that no section or subsection of article III shall apply when the board of commissioners has determined that the section or subsection is logically inconsistent with and unreasonably restrictive of the business of a wholesale dealer. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-71) 
Sec. 6-92. - Application. 
Any wholesale dealer in alcoholic beverages who is licensed by the state, or the agent of such wholesale dealer, shall be granted a license to distribute such beverage for wholesale in the county upon application for a license. The application shall be accompanied by the presentation of satisfactory evidence that the wholesale dealer, or agent of the wholesale dealer, understands and agrees to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-72) 
Sec. 6-93. - Fee. 
(a)  The license fee for each wholesale dealer shall be $1000.00. 
(b)  All license fees shall be paid on or before November 15 for the following calendar year or within ten days of the grant of an application for a license. 
(c)  All license fees shall be paid in full regardless of when a license is granted. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-73; Ord. No. 99-103, § II, 9-21-99; Ord. No. 2016-178, § 3, 12-6-16) 
Secs. 6-94—6-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OPERATING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 6-116. - Commencement of business. 
All licensees under this chapter must, within a six-month period after the issuance of a license, open for business the establishment referred to in the license and begin the sale of the product authorized by such license. Failure to open the establishment and begin the sale as referred to above within the six-month period shall serve as automatic forfeiture and cancellation of the unused license, and no refund of license fees shall be made to the licensee. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-31) 
Sec. 6-117. - Discontinuation of business. 
Any licensee who shall begin the operation of the business and sale of the product or products as authorized in a license, but who shall, for a period of six consecutive months thereafter, cease to operate the business and sale of the product or products authorized by such license shall upon completion of the six-month period automatically forfeit his license. No refund of license fees shall be made to the licensee. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-32) 
Sec. 6-118. - Business hours. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for businesses holding a retail consumption dealer's license to sell, dispense, or deliver alcoholic beverages to any customer or patron of the business between the following hours: 
(1)  2:00 a.m. Sunday and 1:00 p.m. Sunday; 
(2)  12:00 midnight Sunday and 9:00 a.m. Monday; 
(3)  2:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. Tuesday through Saturday, except election day; and 
(4)  2:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on election days. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for businesses holding a retail consumption dealer's license to fail to remove from its retail service area where normal access to the public is available any and all cans, bottles, glasses, mugs, pitchers, cups or other containers used in the consumption of alcoholic beverages or to otherwise allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages on its premises 30 minutes after the business is prohibited from selling, dispensing, or delivering alcoholic beverages to any customer or patron of the business. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for businesses holding a retail dealer's license or wholesale dealer's license to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages between the following hours: 
(1)  12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m.; 
(2)  Christmas Day. 
(d)  It shall not be unlawful for businesses holding a retail dealer's license or wholesale dealer's license to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 2:00 a.m. on New Year's Day on any day of the week, including Sunday. All non-employees shall be off the premises no later than 2:30 a.m. and all employees no later than 3:30 a.m. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-33; Ord. No. 92-135, § I, 12-15-92; Ord. No. 00-154, § I, 12-19-00; Ord. No. 2012-233, § 1, 11-13-12; Ord. No. 2017-79, § 1, 11-21-17) 
Sec. 6-119. - Vacating premises. 
Notwithstanding any other local regulation, whenever a closing time is provided, the premises shall be vacated within 30 minutes by all except personnel of such establishment and no alcoholic beverages shall be dispensed after such closing time. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-34) 
Sec. 6-120. - Authority to purchase alcoholic beverages. 
Licensees may purchase from wholesalers, licensed by the county, alcoholic beverages, designated by their license, in one-fifth of a gallon, liter or larger containers unless a particular brand is not packaged in these sizes; then such licensee may purchase such brand in the nearest size to such containers. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-35) 
Sec. 6-121. - Delivery of alcoholic beverages. 
No deliveries of alcoholic beverages shall be made except on the premises in which such beverages are sold. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-36) 
Sec. 6-122. - Condition of premises. 
All premises shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition and in full compliance with the provisions and regulations governing the conditions of premises used for the storage and sale of food for human consumption. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-37) 
Sec. 6-123. - Signs advertising brand or price prohibited. 
No sign of any kind, painted or electric, advertising any brand or price of alcoholic beverages shall be permitted on the exterior, or in the window, of any licensed premises. No placard or sign of any kind which is visible from the exterior of the licensed premises shall make reference to the price of any alcoholic beverages sold therein. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-38) 
Sec. 6-124. - Minors prohibited from premises. 
Lounges and retail dealers shall not allow minors to be in, frequent or loiter about the licensed premises unless accompanied by an adult. This section shall not apply to restaurants, private clubs or others whose predominant business is other than the sale of alcoholic beverages, for example, grocery or convenience stores. This section shall not apply to minors who are employees of the business. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-39) 
Sec. 6-125. - Disturbances, obscenities prohibited. 
No licensee shall permit any disturbance of the peace, obscenity or any lewd, immoral or improper entertainment, conduct or practices at its place of business. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-40) 
Sec. 6-126. - Reuse of bottles. 
It shall be illegal for the licensee under this chapter to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles or in any other manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-41) 
Sec. 6-127. - Broken seals. 
On the premises of a retail dealer, it shall be unlawful for any person except a licensee, his manager or agent in charge of the licensed premises, to carry into or have in his possession on any premises any alcoholic beverages in the original package, the seal of which has been broken or the original package opened. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-42) 
Sec. 6-128. - Certain sales prohibited. 
No licensee shall sell any alcoholic beverage to any person under the age established by state law, or to any person in an intoxicated condition, or to any person known to such licensee or his employee to be an habitual drunkard or to any person known to such licensee or his employee to be of intemperate habits or of unsound mind. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-43) 
Sec. 6-129. - Underaged persons misrepresenting age. 
It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase alcoholic beverages or to intentionally misrepresent his age in the sale of any alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-44) 
Sec. 6-130. - Sales outside business. 
It shall be unlawful for any sales to be made outside of the place of business licensed for such sale except as permitted in this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-45) 
Sec. 6-131. - Employment of certain persons prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful in any premises to employ any person in any capacity whatsoever, including performers, entertainers and musicians, who has been convicted within the past five years, by this or any other state or by the United States or any other country, of any offense involving the use of or threat of force or violence upon the person of another; any offense involving narcotics, dangerous drugs, or dangerous weapons; any felony crime involving moral turpitude; any offense involving sexual behavior, whether felony or misdemeanor, as set out in O.C.G.A. Title 16, Crimes and Offenses, Chapter 6, Sexual Offenses; or any offense relating to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages. For the purpose of this subsection, a conviction shall include a finding or verdict of guilty, plea of guilty, or a plea of nolo contendere in a criminal proceeding. 
(b)  In addition, it shall be unlawful in any premises to employ any person who takes orders for, dispenses, sells, serves, or delivers an alcoholic beverage, who has been convicted of more than one D.U.I. offense within two years of the date of the application for said permit; or who has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor crime of moral turpitude or as an habitual violator within five years of the date of the application for said permit. For purposes of this subsection, a conviction shall include a finding or verdict of guilty, a plea of guilty, or a plea of nolo contendere, in a criminal proceeding. 
(c)  Minors may be employed but shall not be allowed to take orders for, dispense, sell, serve, deliver, or, in any other manner, to handle alcoholic beverages. However, minors shall not be employed in lounges. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-46; Ord. No. 2006-113, § 1, 8-15-06) 
Sec. 6-132. - Employees list. 
It shall be the duty of all retail consumption dealer licensees to file with the business license division of the community development department the names of all employees who take orders for, dispense, sell, serve, deliver, or, in any manner, to handle alcoholic beverages, with their home addresses, home telephone numbers, and places of employment. Changes in the list of such employees, with the names of new such employees, must be filed with said business license division within five days from the date of any such change. All such employees shall be subject to such investigation rules and regulations as may be deemed necessary from time to time by the business license division. A $30.00 investigation fee shall be paid by all licensees for each such employee; however, any such fee shall not be in addition to any such fee paid in regard to an individual in accordance with or pursuant to section 6-135(c). 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-47; Ord. No. 93-114, § I(2-3-47), 11-16-93; Ord. No. 2006-113, § 2, 8-15-06) 
Sec. 6-133. - Copy of regulations. 
It shall be the duty of the management of the premises licensed under this chapter to maintain a copy of this chapter on such premises and to instruct each and every employee of the terms thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-48) 
Sec. 6-134. - Display of warning signs for driving under the influence required. 
All retail consumption dealers, as defined by this chapter, shall have conspicuously displayed at every exit from the retail location a sign measuring not less than ten inches square, printed in not less than three-quarters inch in height, in a color clearly contrasting to the background of such sign, containing the following language: 
State law provides for conviction of driving under the influence if you are impaired by alcohol to any degree, regardless of your blood alcohol content. 
(Ord. No. 96-71, § I, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 6-135. - Permit required to take order for, dispense, sell, serve, or deliver alcohol by the drink; display of permit; background check and fees; restrictions; penalty; penalty imposed on business. 
(a)  No employee of a business with a retail consumption dealer's license shall take an order for, dispense, sell, serve, or deliver an alcoholic beverage without first obtaining an alcoholic beverage server permit issued by the county police department. 
(b)  Any employee of a business with a retail consumption dealer's license who takes an order for, dispenses, sells, serves, or delivers alcoholic beverages must display on his or her outer clothing a valid alcoholic beverage server permit. 
(c)  Prior to issuing an alcoholic beverage server permit, the police department shall conduct a background check on the applicant and shall collect a non-refundable investigative fee of $20.00 from the applicant to offset the cost of this background check. A regulatory fee shall be due at the time of issuance or renewal of a permit; the 12-month permit fee for an alcoholic beverage server shall be $15.00. The permit is issued to the applicant and is to remain in the applicant's possession until it expires or is destroyed by the applicant. A lost or stolen alcoholic beverage server permit must be reported immediately to the Clayton County Police Department. 
(d)  In addition to the restrictions imposed in subsection 6-131(a), no alcoholic beverage server permit shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of more than one D.U.I. offense within two years of the date of the application for said permit; or, who has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor crime of moral turpitude or as an habitual violator within five years of the date of the application for said permit. For purposes of this subsection, a conviction shall include a finding or verdict of guilty, a plea of guilty, or a plea of nolo contendere, in a criminal proceeding. 
(e)  Any violation of subsection (a) or subsection (b) of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(f)  Any business with a retail consumption dealer's license that allows an employee to violate this section or that allows a person without a valid alcoholic beverage server permit to take an order for, dispense, sell, serve, or deliver an alcoholic beverage shall be punished by a fine at the discretion of the trial judge for each separate violation. It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section for a law enforcement officer or employee authorized by the director of community development to inspect businesses to observe a person without a valid alcoholic beverage server permit take an order for, dispense, sell, serve, or deliver an alcoholic beverage or a person who is taking an order for, dispensing, selling, serving, or delivering alcohol without a valid alcoholic beverage server permit displayed on his or her outer clothing. 
(Ord. No. 2006-114, §§ 1, 2, 8-15-06; Ord. No. 2006-200, § 2, 12-19-06) 
Secs. 6-136—6-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS FOR RETAIL CONSUMPTION 

Sec. 6-156. - Retail consumption districts. 
Retail consumption dealers, except private clubs or sports clubs, shall locate their businesses only in areas designated for such activity from time to time by the board of commissioners. Such areas shall be indicated on a map to be used for such purpose and to be kept and maintained in the office of the department of community development. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-61; Ord. No. 93-122, § 1, 11-16-93; Ord. No. 2005-96, § 1, 8-16-05; Ord. No. 2008-88, § 1, 5-20-08) 
Sec. 6-157. - Fire regulations. 
Where a minimum sleeping or seating capacity is prescribed, the same shall be judged by reasonable standards. The fire department shall, upon the request of the department of community development, inspect such premises and report its findings. All premises licensed under this chapter shall conform at all times with the fire regulations established by the county. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-62) 
Sec. 6-158. - Trains, planes. 
Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on dining or club cars of trains or on airplanes in transit on regular schedules. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-63) 
Sec. 6-159. - Drinks served by employees. 
Drinks shall only be served by employees of the licensee. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-64) 
Sec. 6-160. - Service in back rooms prohibited. 
The sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption by persons in any back room or side room which is not normally open to the general public use is prohibited, except that private parties or conventions, which have been scheduled in advance, may be served in public or private dining rooms or meeting rooms. This prohibition shall not apply to the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption hereunder to the registered guests of any hotel or motel in their designated rooms. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-65) 
Sec. 6-161. - Adult entertainment. 
(a)  Findings; public purpose. Based on the experiences of other urban counties, including but not limited to this county, Fulton County, and Richmond County, Georgia; and other urban municipalities, including but not limited to Atlanta and Smyrna, Georgia, Austin, Texas, Los Angeles, California, and Indianapolis, Indiana, which experiences are relevant to the problems faced by this county; and based on the Austin City Study from Austin, Texas, and other opinions proffered by the county's police department and court personnel, the board of commissioners takes note of the well-known and self-evident conditions attendant to the commercial exploitation of human sexuality which do not vary greatly among generally comparable communities within our country. 
(1)  It is the finding of the board of commissioners that public nudity (either partial or total) under certain circumstances, particularly circumstances related to the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in so-called "nude bars" or establishments offering so-called "nude entertainment" or "adult entertainment," leads to an increase in criminal activity, and economic blight and diminution in property values of the surrounding areas. 
(2)  Among the acts of criminal activity behavior identified with the commercial combination of live nudity and alcohol are disorderly conduct, prostitution, solicitation, drug trafficking, drug use and corruption of public officials. Among the undesirable community conditions identified with the commercial combination of live nudity and alcohol are depression of property values and acceleration of community blight in the surrounding neighborhood, increased allocation of and expenditure for law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, and increased burden on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior hereinabove described. 
(3)  Accordingly, it is in the best interests of the health, welfare, safety and morals of the community to reduce the adverse impact of adult entertainment establishments by limiting the number of such uses, so as to reduce the negative impacts of adult entertainment establishments upon other business uses, neighborhood property values, residential areas and public and semipublic uses, to insure that adult entertainment establishments do not impede development, redevelopment and neighborhood revitalization efforts. 
(4)  The purpose of this section is to prohibit certain types of attire, conduct and activity in the form of adult entertainment within establishments licensed to serve alcoholic beverages, to the end that the many types of criminal activities frequently engendered by such businesses will be curtailed. However, it is recognized that the prohibition of adult entertainment cannot de facto be inclusive, otherwise a protected form of expression would vanish. As to establishments serving alcoholic beverages and offering adult entertainment, this section represents a balancing of competing interests: reduced criminal activity and protection of the neighborhoods through the prohibition of adult entertainment in establishments licensed to sell alcoholic beverages versus the protected rights of adult entertainment establishments and patrons. 
Therefore, the prohibition of adult entertainment in establishments licensed to sell alcoholic beverages is in the public welfare and is a matter of governmental interest and concern to minimize the occurrence of criminal behavior and undesirable community conditions normally associated with establishments which serve alcoholic beverages and provide adult entertainment. To that end, this section is hereby adopted. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Adult entertainment means any form of entertainment that features live performances by topless and/or bottomless dancers, go-go dancers, strippers or similar entertainers, where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
(2)  Retail consumption dealer means any establishment licensed by the county community development department as a retail consumption dealer of alcoholic beverages, or is otherwise licensed to sell, serve, dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises within the unincorporated area of the county. 
(3)  Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: 
a.  Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral-anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellatio, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, sapphism, zooerastia; 
b.  Clearly depicted human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; 
c.  Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus, or masturbation; 
d.  Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, or female breast; 
e.  Masochism, erotic, or sexually oriented torture, beating or the infliction of pain; or 
f.  Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being. 
(4)  Specified anatomical areas means and includes any of the following: 
a.  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region; buttock, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or 
b.  Human male genitalia in a discernable turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
(c)  Enactment. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any establishment licensed as a retail consumption dealer to offer or permit to be offered any adult entertainment on or within the licensed premises. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any establishment licensed as a retail consumption dealer to employ or use a person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any specified anatomical areas. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any establishment licensed as a retail consumption dealer to hold, promote, sponsor or allow any contest promotion, special night, event or any other activity where patrons of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any specified sexual activities. 
(d)  Application. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the business establishment of any mainstream performance house, museum, theater or performing arts if such establishment is otherwise licensed to sell, serve, dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises within the unincorporated area of the county, and if such establishment derives less than 20 percent of its gross annual income from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-66; Ord. No. 93-108, § I, 10-19-93) 
Cross reference— Amusements and entertainments, ch. 10. 
Sec. 6-162. - Pricing. 
(a)  Each licensee shall maintain a schedule of the prices charged for all alcoholic beverages to be served and consumed on the licensed premises or in any room or part thereof. The licensee shall not vary the schedule of prices from day to day or from hour to hour within a single day. The schedule of prices shall be posted in a conspicuous manner so as to be in view of the paying public, consistent with section 6-123, and such schedule shall be effective for not less than one calendar week. 
(b)  No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee shall: 
(1)  Offer or deliver any free alcoholic beverage to any person or group of persons. 
(2)  Deliver more than two alcoholic beverages to one person at one time. 
(3)  Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons any alcoholic beverage at a price less than the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage during the same calendar week, except at private functions not opened to the public. 
(4)  Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons an unlimited number of alcoholic beverages during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not opened to the public. 
(5)  Sell, offer to sell, or deliver alcoholic beverages to any person or group of persons at any one day at prices less than those charged the general public on that day, except at private functions not opened to the public. 
(6)  Sell, offer to sell, or deliver alcoholic beverages, including malt beverages, by the pitcher, except to two or more persons at any one time. 
(7)  Increase the volume of alcohol contained in a drink without increasing proportionately the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage during the same calendar week. 
(8)  Encourage or permit on the licensed premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of alcoholic beverages or the awarding of alcoholic beverages as a prize. 
(c)  No licensee shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the licensed premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  No provision of this section shall be construed to prohibit licensees from offering free food or entertainment at any time, provided all patrons are allowed equal access to such free food, or to prohibit the sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe when sold with meals or to more than one person, or to prohibit any hotel or motel from offering room services to registered guests. Otherwise no food and alcoholic beverage package may be offered by any licensee. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-67) 
Sec. 6-163. - Verification of age. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this Code for any agent, officer or employee of a licensee to fail to properly check the identification of any patron when selling or otherwise providing any alcoholic beverage, which failure results in the underage person being sold, served or possessing any alcoholic beverage. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the term "identification" shall mean any document issued by any governmental agency containing a description of the person so identified, such person's photograph and such person's date of birth. As used in this section, the term "identification" shall include, without being limited to, a passport, a military identification card, a driver's license, or a state department of public safety identification card. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any criminal prosecution which may result from a violation of this section, any licensee employing any officer, agent or employee that fails to comply with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, which failure results in an underaged person being sold or served, or to have in his possession while on the licensee's premises, an alcoholic beverage, may have their license revoked as provided in section 6-33. 
(e)  No licensee shall employ any person who has been convicted of or pled nolo contendere to a violation of this section, or any similar provision from any other jurisdiction, within the preceding ten years. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-68; Ord. No. 92-135, § II, 12-15-92; Ord. No. 93-37, § III, 4-20-93) 
Secs. 6-164—6-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 90. 

Sec. 6-186. - Taxes assessed. 
In addition to the license fees required in this chapter and in addition to the excise taxes levied by the state, all licensees under this chapter shall pay to the county the taxes imposed in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-81) 
Sec. 6-187. - Malt beverages. 
There is hereby imposed an excise tax on the sale of malt beverages as follows: 
(1)  Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons. 
(2)  Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.04167 per ounce. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-82) 
Sec. 6-188. - Wine. 
There is hereby imposed an excise tax, on the first sale or use of wine by the package, which tax shall be $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-83) 
Sec. 6-189. - Distilled spirits by the liter. 
There is hereby imposed an excise tax on the sale of distilled spirits, excluding fortified wines, which tax shall be $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-84) 
Sec. 6-190. - Payment of tax. 
(a)  The excise taxes provided in sections 6-187, 6-188 and 6-189 shall be imposed upon and shall be paid by the licensed wholesale dealer. 
(b)  Each licensee responsible for the payment of the excise tax shall file a report with the county itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of alcoholic beverages, by size and type of container, sold during the month in the county. 
(c)  The wholesale dealer shall remit the tax imposed herein to the county on the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the alcoholic beverages are sold or disposed. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3-85) 
Sec. 6-191. - Distilled spirits by the drink. 
(a)  Consumption. There is hereby imposed a sales tax on the sale of distilled spirits by the drink, which tax shall be three percent of the charge to the public for the beverage. This tax does not apply to the sale of fermented beverages made in whole or in part from malt or any similar fermented beverage. Each licensee shall collect, report and remit such tax in the manner described in sections 6-191(b) through 6-196. 
(b)  Itemized billing; liability for payment of tax. Every licensee shall, at the time of collecting for food and drinks served, give to the purchaser a receipt on which the price of alcoholic beverages served shall be itemized separately. Where the charges for food and drink are satisfied by credit or deferred payment, the payment of the tax to the licensee may be deferred in a like manner; however, the licensee shall be liable therefor at the time and to the extent that such credits are incurred. 
(c)  Collection of tax; information to county. Every licensee or its agent is hereby authorized and directed to collect the tax imposed by this article from purchasers of alcoholic beverages by the drink sold within its licensed premises. Such licensee or agent shall furnish such information as may be requested by the license department to facilitate the collection of this tax. 
(d)  Payment of tax by licensee; collection fee. 
(1)  Due date of taxes. All taxes collected by any licensee or agent under this section shall be due and payable to the county on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective calendar month, as set forth herein. 
(2)  Return; time of filing; persons required to file; execution. On or before the 20th day of the month, a return for the preceding calendar month shall be filed with the department of community development in such form as the department of community development may prescribe by every licensee or agent liable for the payment of tax under this section. 
(3)  Contents of return. All returns shall show the gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink, amount of tax collected or authorized due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the department of community development. 
(4)  Delivery of return and remittance. The person required to file the return shall deliver the return, together with the remittance of the net amount of tax due to the department of community development. 
(5)  Collection fee allowed licensees. Licensees collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment.
