Chapter 54 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; fire department members vested with police powers, § 42-4. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - State Jail Construction and Staffing Act. 
(a)  Authorization to impose and collect additional penalty assessments. The board of commissioners hereby places in effect O.C.G.A. § 15-21-90 et seq., known as the Jail Construction and Staffing Act. To the extent that state law requires action by the board of commissioners, the board hereby authorizes the imposition and collection of additional penalty assessments in criminal and traffic cases and cases involving violations of county ordinances. Further, the board of commissioners hereby authorizes the proceeds derived therefrom to be used for constructing, operating and staffing of jails, correctional institutions and detention facilities by the county. 
(b)  Authority to enter into intergovernmental agreements. The board of commissioners hereby authorizes the chairman to enter into intergovernmental contracts with the various municipalities located within the county providing for the use of the county's detention facility by municipal prisoners. The purpose of this action is to authorize the imposition and collection by the municipal courts of additional penalties as provided for in the Jail Construction and Staffing Act. 
(Code 1973, § 2-2-14) 
Sec. 54-2. - Reserve deputy sheriff unit. 
There is hereby established the reserve deputy sheriff unit under the authority of the administrative operations division of the county sheriff's department for the following purposes: To bring the county sheriff's office closer to the community; to establish a group of trained individuals that can be called upon to assist in a time of need; and for such other purposes as the sheriff may determine necessary. The reserve deputy sheriffs shall serve at the pleasure and discretion of the sheriff and may be called into service at any time that the sheriff considers it necessary. 
(Ord. No. 98-91, § 1, 8-4-98) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 98-91, adopted August 4, 1998, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification of § 1 of said ordinance as § 54-2 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 54-3. - Reserve police officer unit. 
There is hereby established the reserve police officer unit under the authority of the Clayton County Police Department for the following purposes: To bring the county police department closer to the community; to establish a group of trained individuals who can be called upon to assist in a time of need; and for such other purposes as the chief of police may determine necessary. The reserve officers shall serve at the pleasure and discretion of the chief of police and may be called into service at any time the chief considers necessary. 
(Ord. No. 03-120, § 1, 8-19-03) 
Sec. 54-4. - Retention of badge and weapon by retired public safety officers. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
County public safety officer means any county police officer, deputy sheriff, the fire chief and any sworn employee of the fire department who is authorized by the fire chief to carry a firearm on duty, the warden of the county prison and any sworn employee of the prison who is authorized by the warden carry to a firearm on duty, or an investigator employed by the district attorney's office or solicitor general's office. 
Disability means a medical condition that prevents an individual from working as a county public safety officer. 
Reimbursement schedule means the dollar amount the retiring county public safety officer will reimburse the county for the cost of the weapon. For the purpose of this schedule, the age of the weapon is computed from the date the weapon was first put in service by a county public safety agency. For a weapon that is less than three years old the retiring officer shall reimburse the county 80 percent of the county's cost of the weapon but not more than $200.00. For a weapon that is three years old but less than five years old, the retiring officer shall reimburse the county 50 percent of the county's cost of the weapon but not more than $100.00. For a weapon that is five years or more in age, the retiring officer shall reimburse the county $1.00. 
Weapon means a county owned handgun issued to the public safety officer by his agency for official use as a county public safety officer. 
(b)  In recognition of the sacrifice made by our public safety officers who have served at least 15 years with the county and who retire and leave active duty under honorable conditions and in good standing, may retain their weapon and badge as part of their compensation. The retiring public safety officer shall reimburse the county for the cost of the weapon pursuant to the reimbursement schedule. Once the county receives payment, ownership of the weapon shall transfer to the retiring officer and the weapon will be removed from the county's inventory. 
(c)  When a county public safety officer leaves active duty as a result of a disability arising from a line of duty injury, such member shall be entitled as part of such officer's compensation to retain his or her weapon and badge. The county waives reimbursement in such cases and ownership of the weapon shall transfer to the officer and the weapon shall be removed from the county's inventory. 
(d)  The director of human resources is designated by the board of commissioners to act on behalf of the county in determining an employee's qualifications under this section. 
(1)  To determine if the employee meets the 15-year requirement, the director shall calculate each year of service or part thereof that the employee has served either as a county police officer, deputy sheriff, any sworn employee of the fire department who is authorized by the fire chief to carry a firearm on duty, any sworn employee of the prison who is authorized by the warden carry to a firearm on duty, or an investigator employed by the district attorney's office or solicitor general's office or any combination thereof. The total years of service must equal or exceed 15 years. This will only include years of service as a county employee, provided however that investigators for the district attorney's office who are paid in part or in whole by the state, will receive credit for each year or part thereof that they work for the county's district attorney's office. 
(2)  In addition, the director shall determine if the employee has met all other conditions of this section. 
(3)  The decision of the director of human recourses in these matters is final. 
(4)  The employee's department head or elected official shall notify the director of human resource 30 days prior to the employee's last work day before retirement or as close as possible thereto, to allow the director sufficient time to make the determinations required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010-107, § 1, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 2010-248, § 1, 12-14-10) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-248, § 1, adopted Dec. 14, 2010, changed the title of § 54-4 from retention of badge and weapon by retired law enforcement officers to retention of badge and weapon by retired public safety officers. 
Secs. 54-5—54-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISPOSITION OF FOUND, RECOVERED PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Purchases and property disposition, § 2-91 et seq.; sales of county property, § 2-146 et seq. 
State Law reference— Control and disposal of county property generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-9-2. 

Sec. 54-26. - Unclaimed property generally. 
(a)  All personal property coming into the possession of the county sheriff's department or the county police department, from any source, wherein the owner is unknown or wherein the owner cannot be located, wherein the item is not contraband and has no foreseeable evidentiary value and with the exception of motor vehicles, firearms and bicycles, which are covered elsewhere within this Code, shall be disposed of as follows: 
(1)  Every effort shall be made to locate the rightful owner, and, if the owner cannot be located, the procedure for disposition shall be as follows in subsection (2) of this section. 
(2)  The procedure for disposal of unclaimed property generally shall be in accordance with the following: 
a.  Retention following use as evidence. If such property is evidence in any proceeding, it shall be retained for 60 days from the date of final termination of such proceeding. 
b.  Public notice of pending disposition. A notice shall then be placed for five consecutive days in the legal organ of the county specifically describing each item and advising possible owners of items of the method of contacting the county sheriff's department or the county police department. Such notice shall also stipulate a date, time and place such items will be placed for public sale if not claimed, or, if not, converted to use by the county. Such notice shall also stipulate whether such items or groups of items are to be sold in blocks, by lot numbers, by entire list of items or separately. 
c.  Conversion to use by county. Upon written request of a department head of a department of the county, submitted to the board of commissioners and with approval by the board of commissioners, advertised items not claimed by the owner may be converted to use by the department making the request. 
d.  Public sale. Items not claimed by the owners or not converted to county use shall be sold at a sale which shall be conducted not less than seven nor more than 15 days after the advertised notice has been run. The sale shall be to the highest bidder for cash. 
e.  Salvage disposal. If property has not been bid on in two successive sales, it will be considered as salvage and disposed of as other county salvage or nonserviceable equipment is disposed of. 
(b)  Records will be maintained showing the manner in which each item came into possession of the county sheriff's department or county police department, a description of the property, all efforts to locate the owner, any case or docket number, the date of publication of any newspaper notices, and the date of sale. 
(Code 1973, § 2-22-2(a)) 
Sec. 54-27. - Bicycles. 
(a)  Bicycles which may come into possession of the county police department or the county sheriff's department, as a result of being abandoned or stolen, shall be kept for a period of 60 days, and every reasonable effort will be made to determine the owner thereof. If, after 60 days, it cannot be determined who the bicycle rightfully belongs to and there has been no claim for such bicycle, then the bicycle may be donated to any nonprofit organization or group making a request for such to the chief of police or the county sheriff, upon the consent of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Records shall be kept on such bicycles as to when and how acquired, and when and to whom disposition was made, and proper receipts shall be obtained by the police or sheriff's department. 
(Code 1973, § 2-22-2(b)) 
Sec. 54-28. - Firearms and dangerous weapons. 
Firearms and dangerous weapons which come into the possession of the county sheriff's department or the county police department will be disposed of as follows: 
(1)  Firearms which are received for safekeeping or which are received as found property and for which the owner is unknown at the time received may be returned to the owner upon showing of proper proof of ownership. Items which are not claimed by the owner within 90 days shall be disposed of as provided for in subsection (4) of this section. 
(2)  Firearms which are placed in evidence as evidence of a crime will be kept until they have no foreseeable evidentiary value. At that time, if the owner of the firearm is known and upon direction of the sheriff or chief of police, the firearm may be returned to the owner upon showing of proper proof of ownership unless the firearm was used by the owner in the commission of a crime, in which case the firearm will not be returned to the owner except upon receipt of a court order. Firearms which are not claimed by the owner within 90 days shall be disposed of as provided for in subsection (4) of this section. 
(3)  Dangerous weapons other than firearms which were received as recovered or found property and which have no foreseeable evidentiary value may be returned to the owner, except for contraband items or items which would be illegal for a citizen to possess. Dangerous weapons which were used by the owner in the commission of a crime will not be returned to the owner. Items not claimed by the owner within 90 days and items not returnable to the owner will be destroyed as provided for in subsection (4) of this section. 
(4)  The procedure for disposal of firearms and other dangerous weapons which are unclaimed shall be in accordance with the following: 
a.  Public notice of pending disposition; time limitations for disposal. An effort will be made, by certified mail, to notify the known owner of all firearms and dangerous weapons, except those excluded by this subsection or other state or federal laws, or by having a notice placed for five successive days in a county newspaper, if the owner is unknown, specifically describing each item and advising possible owners of the items of the method for contacting the county sheriff's department or county police department. The advertised firearms will not be disposed of less than seven days or more than 15 days after the last advertising notice has run. 
b.  Conversion to use by county. Advertised firearms not claimed by the owner, firearms not returned to the owner because of the operation of this subsection or any other state or federal law, and any other dangerous weapon not returnable to the owner may be converted over to use by the county sheriff's department or county police department upon a written request being submitted to the board of commissioners and upon approval of the request by the board of commissioners. A record will be maintained of each weapon or other dangerous weapons which have been converted over to county use and will include a complete description of each item and the use to which each is to be put. The items will also be included on the property books of the department which has custody of the item. 
c.  Destruction. Any firearms or dangerous weapons which are not converted over to county use as provided for in this section will be disposed of by having the items melted down until they no longer are of value or use as a weapon. Records will be maintained showing a complete description of each item destroyed and will be signed by at least two witnesses to their destruction. 
(Code 1973, § 2-22-2(c)) 
Sec. 54-29. - Contraband items. 
Contraband items which have no foreseeable evidentiary value will be disposed of by the county sheriff's department or the county police department in such a manner that will insure that the items are no longer of value and cannot be recovered by anyone, or the items will be turned over to the proper county, state or federal agency for disposition. A record will be maintained of the items which have been destroyed. 
(Code 1973, § 2-22-2(d)) 
Secs. 54-30—54-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALARM SYSTEMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, adopted Oct. 19, 2004, amended art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, said article pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Ord. No. 2002-145, § 1, adopted Nov. 19, 2002; as amended. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 54-51. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to regulate the installation and use of alarm systems, to establish standards for, controls of, and maintenance of the various alarm systems that are intended to bring about police departments, fire department and/or other emergency department response, and to provide for user fees and penalties for violations. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-52. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices designated and arranged to detect and signal an unauthorized intrusion into the premises, to signal an attempted burglary, robbery or other criminal activity in or upon the premises, to signal a fire in or upon the premises, a medical emergency needing medical attention, and/or an ambulance, or like occurrences. 
Enforcement authority means the county, through the communications department, fire department, and police department. 
Alarm administrator means the person designated by the enforcement authority to administer, control and review false alarm reduction efforts and activities, and the enforcement of this ordinance through due process of law. 
Alarm company means any business operated by an individual, partnership, corporation or other entity, which is licensed to sell, lease, maintain, service, repair, alter, replace, move, install or monitor an alarm system at an alarm site. 
Owner means the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises having an alarm system regulated under the provisions of this article. 
Owner means, as well, the person who has control of the premises on which any alarm system which is regulated under the provisions of this article is in operation. 
Authorized alarm means the activation of an alarm system signal resulting in a response by the police, fire or other county emergency department where actual events or emergencies (as described in Alarm system definition above) for which the alarm system has been installed have, in fact, occurred. 
Unauthorized alarm means the activation of an alarm system signal resulting in a response by the police, fire or other county emergency department where none of the events or emergencies (as described in Alarm system definition above) for which the alarm system has been installed have, in fact, occurred. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-53. - Scope. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to the installation, alteration, equipment, use and maintenance of alarm systems installed within the jurisdiction of the county, after January 16, 1996. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-54. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  An alarm system installed in a motor vehicle; or 
(2)  An alarm system installed upon the premises of a federal, state, county or municipal government, or body politic of such governments, or the county school system. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-55. - Validity of other laws. 
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to prevent the enforcement of other laws or ordinances which prescribe more restrictive limitations. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-56. - Enforcement responsibility. 
Enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the unauthorized alarm division of the county communications department. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-57. - Liability of county. 
The governing authority of the county shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm messages or signals received by the county's communications department are given appropriate attention and are acted upon with dispatch. The county shall not be liable for any omission or neglect regarding the inspection of the installation or alteration of equipment, transmission of alarm signals, alarm messages, or the relaying of any such signals or messages to the communications department. Further, the county shall not be liable for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of a signal from an alarm system, or for the failure or neglect of the communications department or any person or agency providing dispatch or monitoring services to properly notify the county's police, fire or other emergency response departments. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-58. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who owns, leases or occupies property or controls the premises and installs or has installed an alarm system on the premises without obtaining a permit therefore, or alters or has altered an existing alarm system without a permit therefore; or violates any other provision of this article or any regulations promulgated pursuant hereto shall be guilty of the violation of this article and, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 for each violation, or up to 60 days in jail, or both, as determined by the court. 
(b)  Any person who intentionally activates any alarm system for any reason other than for those authorized by this article, or during controlled testing of equipment, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or up to 60 days in jail, or both, as determined by the court. 
(c)  Any person who pleads guilty, is found guilty by the court of violating any provision of this article, or enters a plea of nolo contendere to a citation issued under provisions of this article, may have any business license issued by the county suspended or revoked. Procedures for such suspension or revocation of a business license shall be the same as those set forth in the county occupational license ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-59. - Installation or alteration; permits required. 
Any owner, authorized agent or alarm company installing or altering an alarm system shall apply to the permitting authority on a form supplied by the permitting authority for a permit to have the alarm system installed or altered on the premises. A registration form shall be completed at the time a permit is issued. No such alarm system may be installed or altered after January 16, 1996, prior to the issuance of a permit by the permitting authority. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-60. - Installation or alteration standards. 
The installation and alteration of alarm systems shall be in accordance with Article 760, Fire Protective Signaling Systems, of the National Electrical Code, NFPA 70-1975, and the following NFPA standards: 
(1)  Standard 71, standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of central station signaling systems; 
(2)  Standard 72-B, standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of auxiliary protective signaling systems for fire alarm service; 
(3)  Standard 72-C, standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of remote station protective signaling system; 
(4)  Standard 72-D, standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of remote stations protective signaling systems for watchman, fire alarm, and supervisory service; 
(5)  Standard 72-E, standard on automatic fire detectors; and 
(6)  Standard 74, standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of household fire warning equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-61. - Prohibited equipment. 
An owner or alarm company shall not use or operate, attempt to use or operate, or cause to be used or operated, or arrange, adjust, program or otherwise provide or install any device or combination of devices that will, upon being activated, either mechanically, electronically, or by any other automatic means, call and deliver a recorded message to any telephone number assigned to the county communications department. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-62. - Prohibited connection. 
Except as otherwise authorized by the director of communications, an owner or alarm company shall not place, install, join, connect or otherwise locate any central station alarm system equipment or device for direct access with the county communications department. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-63. - Responsibility for installation and operation. 
The owner of an alarm system shall be responsible for the proper installation and operation of the alarm system and shall obtain a written description of the function of the system along with the procedure and means for activating and deactivating the system. The owner or owners of an alarm system also shall be responsible when providing access to the activation or deactivation of the system to a third party. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-63.1. - Responsibility of an alarm company. 
(a)  Any alarm company performing or providing monitoring services shall: 
(1)  Attempt to make contact with the alarm owner or responsible party to verify the need for dispatch for every alarm signal (except Duress or Holdup alarm activation) before requesting law enforcement response to an alarm system signal; 
(2)  Ensure that all alarm users of alarm systems equipped with a Duressor Holdup alarm are given instruction as to the proper use of such alarm; 
(3)  Maintain and communicate accurate information about the name and phone number for the location to the 9-1-1 operator when requesting dispatch; 
(4)  Communicate accurate information about the location (e.g., front door) or zone (e.g., warehouse) of the alarm and the type of alarm activation (e.g., audible, silent, interior, perimeter) to the 9-1-1 operator when requesting dispatch; and 
(5)  Provide and maintain current and accurate tenant information as requested by enforcement authority. The information furnished and secured pursuant to this article is and shall be personal in nature and confidential and not subject to public inspection except where specifically required under provisions of the Georgia Public Records Act. 
(b)  Any alarm company may: 
(1)  Be issued a citation for violation of this article for failure to verify, if the existence of a consistent pattern is determined during review of location activity, or if there exists a written policy against verification; 
(2)  Be subject to a $25.00 fee if the alarm administrator determines that an on-site alarm company employee directly caused the false alarm, provided in this situation, the false alarm will not be counted against the alarm owner; 
(3)  Be subject to a citation if an alarm company employee has provided to the enforcement authority a false written statement concerning the inspection of an alarm site and/or the performance of an alarm system; and 
(4)  Be subject to a $25.00 fee per dispatch if the alarm administrator determines that an alarm company has requested dispatch for a resident or tenant no longer occupying a location from which a signal is received; and 
(5)  Be subject to established penalties for violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-63.2. - Responsibility of apartment complexes as owners. 
(a)  Any apartment complex owner providing (to tenants) alarm systems already installed in those apartments leased to tenants or having any alarm systems installed on their premises by tenants shall: 
(1)  Notify tenant of any scheduled entrance by maintenance personnel into premises; 
(2)  Ensure any complex personnel entering a tenant's apartment is aware of any alarm system and has the information necessary and ability to activate and/or deactivate said system prior to entering or leaving apartment; 
(3)  Ensure any alarm company contracted by complex management is provided prompt current and accurate information about the name and phone number of current tenant; and 
(4)  Maintain and provide current and accurate tenant information to enforcement authority as requested, provided, however, the information furnished and secured pursuant to this article is and shall be personal in nature and confidential and not subject to public inspection except where specifically required under provisions of the Georgia Public Records Act. 
a.  Any apartment complex owner may: 
1.  Be subject to a $25.00 fee if the alarm administrator determines that an employee or paid contractor of the apartment complex owner directly caused the false alarm. In this situation, the false alarm will not be counted against the tenant (owner) in possession; 
2.  Be subject to a citation for failure to notify tenants of any scheduled entrance into apartment if a consistent pattern exists; 
3.  Be subject to a $25.00 fee per dispatch if the alarm administrator determines that any alarm company contracted by the apartment complex management has requested dispatch for a resident or tenant no longer occupying a location from which a signal is received; and 
4.  Be subject to a citation for any violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-64. - Unauthorized alarm; user fees. 
Any owner who shall have in excess of three unauthorized alarms within a consecutive 365-day period (12-month period) immediately preceding the last unauthorized alarm shall be deemed in violation of this article and be subject to a user fee of $25.00 per each unauthorized alarm in excess of the first three unauthorized alarm occurrences. Any owner who shall have in excess of six unauthorized alarms within a consecutive 365-day period (12-month period) immediately preceding the last unauthorized alarm shall be deemed in violation of this article and be subject to a user fee of $50.00 per unauthorized alarm in excess of six unauthorized alarm occurrences. After nine unauthorized alarms within a consecutive 365-day period (12-month period) immediately preceding the last unauthorized alarm, the matter may be referred to the enforcement authority for appropriate action which may include the issuance of a citation and prosecution for violation of this article. Notwithstanding anything contained in this section to the contrary, an owner installing or having installed on the premises a new alarm system (pursuant to a properly issued permit) shall be granted a grace period of 30 days beginning with the date of the new installation during which grace period the user fees provided herein shall not apply. This grace period is dependent upon the enforcement agency's receipt of documented notification, from the alarm owner, of a new alarm system installed on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-65. - Right of inspection. 
After the occurrence of three unauthorized alarms, as provided in the preceding section, the enforcement authority shall have the right to inspect or cause to be inspected the alarm system at such premises. The enforcement authority may prescribe necessary corrective action resulting from the inspection, and shall give notice to the owner of any such action. The enforcement authority shall also have the right to require alarm owner to have an alarm company modify the alarm system to be more false alarm resistant and/or to provide additional alarm user training as appropriate. Any and all corrective actions shall be performed at the alarm owner's expense. A failure to comply with such corrective action within 30-days from the receipt of notice shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-66. - Deactivation. 
The owner shall be responsible for deactivating or causing to be deactivated the alarm system within a reasonable time following notification by the enforcement authority or any other authorized county department providing notice. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-67. - Exception and force majeure. 
In determining the number of unauthorized alarms chargeable to an owner or alarm company, certain alarms shall be excluded as an unauthorized alarm if such alarm was determined to be caused under any one or more of the following circumstances: 
(1)  There is physical or tangible evidence of criminal activity or unauthorized entry onto the protected premises; 
(2)  Earthquake or other natural occurrence causing structural damage to the protected premises; 
(3)  High winds sufficient to activate motion detection systems or causing physical damage to the protected premises; 
(4)  Flooding of the protected premises due to overflow of natural drainage; 
(5)  Lightning bolt causing physical damage to the protected premises; 
(6)  Telephone line malfunction verified by a telephone company official; 
(7)  Electrical service interruption verified by the electrical service supplier; 
(8)  An alarm caused on the reasonable mistaken belief that a burglary, robbery, or other criminal activity, fire or other emergency is in progress; or 
(9)  The generation of an unauthorized alarm which is beyond the reasonable control of the system user as determined by the system provider and the enforcement authority. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-68. - Confidentiality of information. 
The information furnished and secured pursuant to this article is and shall be personal in nature and confidential and not subject to public inspection except where specifically required under provisions of the Georgia Public Records Act. Any employee of the licensing authority, or other person providing the confidential information secured hereunder to any unauthorized person, or using the information to the detriment of the owner, shall be guilty of a violation of this article and subject to the penalties hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-69. - Regulations. 
The enforcement authority, or other county departments having an interest therein, may from time to time promulgate such rules and regulations as it deems proper concerning the permit, application process, alarm installation and alteration, use and maintenance, testing of alarms, and any other procedures concerning alarm systems. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-70. - Automatic shut-off. 
No person shall operate any audible alarm system that does not have an automatic 15-minute shut-off after activation. The enforcement authority shall take all appropriate actions to shut off an audible alarm that does not automatically shut off within 15 minutes of activation. An automatic 15-minute shut-off feature shall be required in any alarm system installed or altered after July 1, 2002. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 54-71. - Appeals. 
Any person who is of the opinion that a user fee contemplated by this article has been incorrectly assessed may appeal such assessment to the director of the department of communications (the "director") or his appointee. The appeal shall be in writing and be received by the department of communications within ten days from the receipt of notice of the assessment. Following the receipt of the appeal, the director or his appointee shall schedule a hearing not less than 30 days from the receipt of the appeal, and notice thereof shall be provided to all parties having an interest in the disposition of the appeal. The decision of the director or his appointee shall be provided to the parties attending the hearing within ten days of the hearing. If unsatisfied with the decision of the director or his appointee, the party appealing the assessment may thereafter appeal such decision to the board of commissioners in writing. 
(Ord. No. 2004-164, § I, 10-19-04) 
Chapter 58 - FACTORY-BUILT HOUSING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, adopted May 30, 2017, amended ch. 58 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 58, §§ 58-26—58-30, 58-41—58-45, pertained to manufactured homes and trailers, and derived from Code 1973, §§ 2-17-16—2-17-25. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
State Law reference— Classification of mobile homes as a separate class of property for ad valorem property tax purposes, Ga. Const. art. 7, sec. 1, par. 3; The Uniform Standards Code for Manufactured Homes Act, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-130 et seq.; regulations for septic tanks in unincorporated areas; conformity prerequisite to building permit, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.1; registration and licensing of dealers, manufacturers and persons transporting mobile homes, O.C.G.A. § 40-2-36; removal of transportable housing from lands subject to writ of possession, O.C.G.A. § 44-7-59; ad valorem taxation of mobile homes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-440 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND HOME PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-1. - Purpose. 
It is the intent of this ordinance to promote land use compatibility, protect property values and ensure an adequate minimum living space standard. The construction, placement, installation, and relocation of manufactured homes after the effective date of this ordinance shall be subject to the requirements and procedures set forth herein. The requirements and procedures of this ordinance shall be in addition to the rules and regulations of each underlying zoning district, including but not limited to, minimum lots, yard and building spacing, percentage of lot coverage, off-street parking requirements and required foundations. It is not the intent of this ordinance to address, interfere, or intrude upon the safety and construction standards for manufactured homes that are reserved exclusively for federal regulation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
DIVISION 2. - MANUFACTURED HOMES 

Sec. 58-2. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
Manufactured home means a structure, used or intended to be used as a dwelling unit, transportable in one or more sections, which in the traveling mode is eight feet or more in width, or 40 feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, encloses 320 or more square feet of floor area; and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling, with or without permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, including the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems contained therein. "Manufactured home" includes any structure that meets all of the requirements of this subsection except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the Secretary of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. §5401, et seq. For purposes of this ordinance, a "manufactured home" does not include a structure which otherwise complies with this subsection, but which was built prior to June 15, 1976, which units shall be classified as "mobile homes." 
Mobile home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight feet or more in width or 40 feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein and manufactured prior to June 15, 1976. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-3. - Mobile homes prohibited. 
No mobile home shall be permitted within the county. Any mobile home located in the county legally, prior to the enactment of this subchapter and used and occupied as a residential dwelling shall be allowed to remain, but shall not be replaced with another mobile home as defined in section 58-2. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-4. - Unlawful parking, use or location of manufactured homes. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to park, locate or permit the parking or location of any manufactured home upon any lot, street or tract of land within the county, unless the parking or location of said manufactured home meets the requirements of section. 58-5. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-5. - Permissible parking or location. 
(a)  A manufactured home may be placed, located or permitted to remain within the county, if and only if, it is situated: 
(1)  In a manufactured home park which is licensed pursuant to the terms of this Code of Ordinances; or 
(2)  Upon a site that such home has continuously occupied prior to and since the effective date hereof, provided that such occupation was lawful on that date, and further provided that the continued occupation thereof does not pose a significant danger to the health or safety of persons within the manufactured homes or others. 
(b)  The exemption for existing manufactured homes shall apply to the manufactured home being occupied prior to and at the time of the adoption of this section as defined in subsection (a)(2) above, and shall include any replacement manufactured homes for such site provided that such replacement is made within three months of the date the existing manufactured home being replaced has been damaged or destroyed, if the replacement manufactured home meeting the manufactured home standards can meet the setback, distance, and all other requirements found in this Code. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park, place or locate a manufactured home at any location not authorized by this chapter, or to permit or allow any manufactured home to remain within the county in any location not authorized pursuant to this chapter. 
(d)  Any manufactured home lawfully placed, parked or located within the county, shall conform to all the requirements of this chapter, concerning specific use permits, setbacks, anchoring and skirting, and any other requirement imposed by this chapter. 
(e)  A recreational vehicle may not be placed or parked on any property except as specifically permitted by this chapter. 
(f)  Any person, firm or corporation who desires to park or locate a manufactured home as permitted in this chapter, shall make application for a use and occupancy permit with the Department of Community Development. The fee for the use and occupancy permit shall be $0.15 per square foot on enclosure. Before granting such permit, the Department of Community Development shall insure that the following requirements are met in section 58-6 below: 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-6. - General provisions relating to manufactured homes. 
Each manufactured home being constructed, installed, located, or relocated within Clayton County shall comply with the following design standards: 
(1)  The pitch of the roof shall have a minimum vertical rise of three feet for each 12 feet of horizontal run within tolerances and the roof shall be finished with composition, fiberglass, slate, concrete, asphalt, or wood shingles, or non-reflective, crimped metal sheets. 
(2)  The exterior siding shall consist of wood, hardboard, brick, masonry, or aluminum and be comparable in composition, appearance, and durability to the exterior siding commonly used in conventional homes. 
(3)  The tongue, axles, transporting lights, and towing apparatus from each manufactured home shall be removed after placement or relocation on a lot or parcel and before occupancy. 
(4)  Landings and steps leading away from all exterior doors shall be designed and constructed in accordance with state law and Clayton County Ordinances, said state law provisions being expressly incorporated by reference as part of this requirement. 
(5)  A foundation or curtain wall, unpierced except for required ventilation and access, and constructed of masonry or acceptable alternative materials shall be constructed and installed in compliance with county ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-7. - Granting of use and occupancy permit. 
The Department of Community Development of the county shall make a prompt investigation of any application for a use and occupancy permit, as specified in this subchapter, and shall grant the application for permit if the manufactured home meets the requirements specified herein. Failure of the applicant for a permit to meet all the requirements of this subchapter shall be grounds for refusal to allow the applicant to connect to the water, sewer and/or gas service of the county and shall further be grounds for denial of the permit. Any application shall be deemed approved and granted unless the Department of Community Development denies the application in writing within 45 days from receipt of the application setting forth the reason for the denial. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-8. - Parking of more than one home per lot. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, to park, keep or permit the parking of more than one manufactured home upon any lot or tract of land within the county, regardless of the size of the lot or tract, unless the manufactured home is located within a duly licensed manufactured home park. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-9. - Existing manufactured homes. 
(a)  This subchapter does not make unlawful any mobile home or manufactured home already in place and complying with all laws when this subchapter becomes effective. 
(b)  However, after the effective date of this subchapter, if any nonconforming mobile home or manufactured home is removed from its location, the following shall apply: 
(c)  If it is a mobile home, it shall not be allowed to relocate within the county; and 
(d)  If it is manufactured home, all provisions of this subchapter shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-10. - Inspection. 
Officials of the county may enter the premises of any proposed or existing place where any manufactured home is located in order to inspect for compliance with this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-11. - Non-liability. 
The county and its officers, agents and employees shall have no liability of any nature for any actions, omissions or other matters in any way concerning the subject matter of this subchapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-12. - Conflict. 
All other ordinances of the county and all other laws shall apply according to their terms to the subject matter of this subchapter, except as this subchapter expressly and specifically contradicts the ordinances or laws. The fact that this subchapter specifically invokes some other laws and ordinances shall not mean that still other laws and ordinances not specifically invoked do not apply. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
DIVISION 3. - MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS 

Sec. 58-13. - Definitions. 
The terms utilized herein shall have the same meaning or definition as given the terms in section 58-2 of this code of ordinances, as amended. 
Manufactured home park means any area, lot, parcel or tract held in common ownership, or for common operation and on which individual portions of said area, lot, parcel or tract is leased for the placement of manufactured homes as a primary residence. Manufactured home park shall be synonymous with a mobile home park, trailer park, and other like living communities. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-14. - Existing manufactured home parks. 
(a)  This subchapter does not make unlawful any manufactured home park which is already in place and conforming with all laws at the date this subchapter becomes effective, provided the manufactured home park shall make annual application for license to the county, as required herein. It is further provided that, if after the effective date hereof, a manufactured home park or mobile home park in existence at the time of the passage of this subchapter does not conform to the requirements of division 3, no manufactured home may be placed or located within the park unless and until the park conforms to the requirements of this division. 
(b)  It is the intent of this subchapter to cause existing manufactured home parks or to be brought up to the minimum standards of division 3. 
(c)  Each manufactured home park that is not in conformity with the provisions contained in this article, other than the licensure requirement addressed below, shall come into compliance with all provisions within two years. 
(d)  Any lot containing more than one manufactured home, must become licensed as a manufactured home park within 60 days of the adoption of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-15. - Licenses for manufactured home parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, their agents servants or employees to operate or provide parking space for two or more manufactured homes upon any lot or tract of land within the county unless the owner, operator or their agents, servants or employees have first made application for and secured a valid license to operate a manufactured home park issued by the county only upon compliance with this subchapter and section 58-16 below. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation desiring to operate a licensed manufactured home park shall file an application for a license which shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  A description of the property upon which the manufactured home park is to be constructed; 
(3)  Plans and specifications for the manufactured home park which must conform to the requirements of this chapter; 
(4)  Telephone numbers where the applicant may be contacted; 
(5)  An affirmative statement that applicant fully understands that no permit shall be issued until all the construction work has been completed in accordance with the requirements of this chapter, the Plumbing Code and all other ordinances of the county applicable thereto. 
(6)  Any license issued hereunder shall be valid for one year and the owner or operator of the manufactured home park shall be required to apply annually for a renewal of the license from the county. The Department of Community Development of the county is hereby designated has the power to administer the licensing program described herein and to grant and deny all licenses all applications. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-16. - Minimum requirements. 
(a)  Manufactured home parks are permitted only in the RMH zoning district. 
(b)  The minimum area of a manufactured home park shall be 20 acres. 
(c)  The minimum lot or space site shall be 7,200 square feet. 
(d)  The minimum side lot set back shall be ten feet. 
(e)  The minimum distance between any manufactured home or house trailer and a house trailer or manufactured home on an adjoining lot or space site shall be 20 feet. 
(f)  The front lot or space line set back shall be 25 feet. 
(g)  All streets and driveways within the manufactured home park shall be lighted between sunset and sunrise with electric lights emitting light at an intensity of at least 5,000 lumens, and the light poles shall be no more than 250 feet apart. 
(h)  The maximum overall park density shall not exceed five (5) units per gross acre. 
(i)  Adequate off-street parking shall be provided. 
(j)  Each home in a manufactured home park shall be provided with safety tie-downs in conformance with Clayton County building code requirements. 
(k)  An adequate supply of pure, potable water for drinking and domestic purposes shall be supplied by pipes to all buildings and home spaces within the park. Each home stand shall be provided with an approved cold water connection and a tap (hydrant) constructed in accordance with the plumbing standards adopted by Clayton County, Georgia. 
(l)  The area around and underneath each home unit shall be kept clean and free from collection of refuse, rubbish, glass bottles or other unsightly material. 
(m)  Refuse control shall be provided by either of the following methods: 
(1)  Centrally located trash collection stations shall be provided for each 20 home spaces, or fraction thereof, conveniently located to serve tenants, not more than 200 feet from any space served, and shall be conveniently located for collection. Such station shall be constructed with a concrete floor and appropriate enclosure as stated in App. A, section 6.9, Accessory Structures. 
(2)  A centrally located trash compactor. 
(n)  No manufactured home park shall be served by a privy. 
(o)  Every manufactured home park shall be equipped at all times with fire equipment in good working order and of such type, size, number and location as to satisfy applicable fire regulations of Clayton County; provided further, that no open fires or burning of leaves or other refuse shall be permitted within the boundaries of any manufactured home park. 
(p)  A minimum of 15 percent of the gross acreage of the manufactured home park shall be set aside for the recreational use by residents of the manufactured home park. Said recreational park shall be one contiguous tract or several tracts each no smaller than one-half acre and located within the manufactured home park in such a manner as to be convenient to all its residents. The recreational park shall be located on land suitable for park development and shall contain a sufficient amount of play equipment designed for elementary-school-age children. 
(q)  Planted buffers shall be required per App. A, section 6.35, Buffer Yard Standards. 
(r)  Coin-operated laundries for the use of the residents of the manufactured home park shall be permitted within enclosed buildings inside the park. Building structures containing said laundries may also contain vending machines and recreational rooms and activities. 
(s)  The regulations governing manufactured home parks prescribed by the health department, as well as other county or state regulations, shall be complied with. 
(t)  Each manufactured home space shall have the following: 
(1)  A concrete patio at least four inches thick with minimum dimensions of 40 feet by eight feet within each trailer space; 
(2)  A wooden deck built to Clayton County specifications and having a surface area of at least 320 square feet; or 
(3)  A combination of a concrete patio at least four inches thick and a wooden deck built to Clayton County specifications, provided the combined surface area (excluding steps) is at least 320 square feet. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-17. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation who commits any of the following shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than $500.00: 
(1)  Any violation of this article; or 
(2)  Providing false information to a county official concerning licensing or permitting under this article or compliance herewith. Each day or portion of a day during which any violation occurs or continues shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
ARTICLE II. - INDUSTRIALIZED HOUSING AND INDUSTRIALIZED BUILDINGS 

Sec. 58-18. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases shall have the following meanings in this division unless otherwise clearly indicated in the text. Words not defined shall be interpreted in their usual sense. 
Industrialized housing means a residential structure that is designed for the use and occupancy of one or more families, that is constructed in one or more modules or constructed using one or more modular components built at a location other than the permanent residential site, and that is designed to be used as a permanent residential structure when the modules or modular components are transported to the permanent residential site and are erected or installed on a permanent foundation system. The term includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems. The term does not include any residential structure that is in excess of three stories or 49 feet in height as measured from the finished grade elevation at the building entrance to the peak of the roof. The term shall not mean nor apply to: 
(1)  Housing constructed of sectional or panelized systems not utilizing modular components; or 
(2)  Any ready-built home which is constructed so that the entire living area is contained in a single unit or section at a temporary location for the purpose of selling it and moving it to another location. 
Modular component means a structural portion of any dwelling or building that is constructed at a location other than the homesite in such a manner that its construction cannot be adequately inspected for code compliance at a homesite without damage or without removal of a part thereof and reconstruction. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-19. - Application of ordinances of the county to industrialized structures. 
All provisions of the ordinances of the county shall apply to the construction, placement and the use of any industrialized building or industrialized housing on any property within the county on the same basis as such ordinances are applicable to the construction and the use of any other structure except to the extent such ordinances of the county are inconsistent with state law, or are in conflict with the provisions of this article. For purposes of all ordinances of the county, the placement of an industrialized building or industrialized housing shall be deemed the construction of a structure. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-20. - Conformance to uniform codes. 
Any industrialized building or industrialized housing erected or installed in the county shall be constructed in accordance with the requirements and standards of adopted codes within the county. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-21. - Submission of plans and specifications. 
Prior to the issuance of any permit for the installation of any industrialized building or industrialized housing in the county, the applicant shall submit to the building official a complete set of design plans and specifications bearing the insignia of the Commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, as set out in Ga. Comp. R. & Regs. 110-2-1-.04. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Sec. 58-22. - Decal or insignia required. 
No industrialized building or industrialized housing shall be installed in the county unless it bears an approved decal or insignia pursuant to the rules of the Georgia Department of Community Affairs reflecting that the structure has been inspected at the manufacturing plant or facility. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 5-30-17) 
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference— Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-182, § 1, adopted Nov. 20, 2007, added ch. 62, art. I(tit.) to read as herein set out. Section 1 further provided that all existing code sections now within chapter 62 are hereby adopted by reference and placed within the new article I entitled "general". 

Sec. 62-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2006-145, § 1, adopted Oct. 3, 2006, repealed § 62-1 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to fortunetelling and similar practices prohibited as enacted by Code 1973, § 2-19-1. The users attention is directed to chapter 22, art. XI for similar provisions. 
Sec. 62-2. - False emergency alarms. 
No person shall intentionally make, turn in or give a false alarm of fire or of need for police or ambulance assistance, or aid or abet in the commission of such an act. 
(Code 1973, § 2-19-2) 
Sec. 62-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 01-41, § 1, adopted April 17, 2001, repealed § 62-3 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to sounds and noises prohibited; violation. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 62-3.1. - Policy and purpose. 
It is declared to be the public policy and purpose of the county board of commissioners to utilize its police powers to protect and promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the people of this county. The board of commissioners recognizes that its citizens derive numerous economic and personal benefits from the use of devises that emit noises. There are, nonetheless, measurable damages and injuries to the environment and to the public health which may be directly attributable to loud, unnecessary, or unusually disturbing sound or noise which has a detrimental effect on the health and welfare of the citizenry and an individual's right to peaceful and quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, the board of commissioners finds that this Code section is necessary for the immediate preservation of the peace, health, safety, welfare, and prosperity of the citizens of Clayton County. However, nothing in this Code section is intended to deter individuals from lawfully exercising the individual right to freedom of speech or any other freedom guaranteed under the Constitutions of the United States of America or of the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 01-41, § 1, 4-17-01) 
Sec. 62-3.2. - Prohibited noises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual sound or noise which either disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of a reasonable person, and which is audible to such person from a distance of 50 feet or more from the point of origin of the sound or noise. A reasonable person is defined as a person of ordinary sensibilities with normal hearing ability. 
(Ord. No. 01-41, § 1, 4-17-01) 
Sec. 62-3.3. - Specific prohibitions. 
In addition to the general prohibitions set out above, the following specific acts are declared to be loud, disturbing, and unnecessary noises in violation of this section; provided however, these enumerations shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, or other vehicle on any street or public place except as a danger warning; the creation of any unreasonable loud or harsh sound by means of any signaling device and the sounding of any device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time; the use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any signaling device when traffic is held up for any reason. 
(2)  Radios, phonographs and similar devices. The using, operating, or permitting to be played, used, or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, tape recorder, compact disc player, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of a reasonable person or at any time with a volume louder than necessary for the convenient hearing of the reasonable person who is in the room, vehicle, or chamber, in which the machine or device is operated, and who is a voluntary listener thereto. The operation of any set, instrument, phonograph, recorder, compact disc player, or other machine, or device any day between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the building, structure, or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(3)  Loudspeakers and amplifiers for advertising. The using, operating, or permitting to be played, used, or operated, of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure. Announcements over loudspeakers can only be made by the announcer in person and without the aid of any mechanical device. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing on the public streets, particularly any day between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of a reasonable person in any office, dwelling, hotel, or other type of residence or of any reasonable person in the vicinity. 
(5)  Steam whistles. The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger or upon request of proper county authorities. 
(6)  Exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motor boat except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. The use of special or modified standard equipment exhaust devices on automotive vehicles to increase or modify the sound emitted by the exhaust is prohibited. 
(7)  Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded, or in a manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling, or other noise. 
(8)  Loading, unloading and opening boxes. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates, and containers. 
(9)  Construction or repair of buildings. The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration, or repair of any building, as well as the operation of any piledriver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist, or any similar equipment attended by loud or unusual noise other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. on weekdays and 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Saturdays. Provided, however, the community development department shall have the authority, upon determining that the loss or inconvenience which would result to any party in interest would be extraordinary and of such nature as to warrant a special consideration, to grant a permit for a period not to exceed ten days within which time such work and operation may take place Monday through Saturday within the hours of 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. Sunday construction work which warrants special consideration can be approved by the director of community development after careful review of the facts surrounding the request for permission to work on Sundays. Any Sunday work permit can be revoked if the applicant does not follow the conditions of the permit, or by the director of community development upon receiving complaints from adjoining property owners. In no case shall permission be given to work more than four consecutive Sundays without the approval of the board of commissioners. 
(10)  Schools, courts, places of worship and hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, place of worship, or court, while in use, or adjacent to any hospital which unreasonably interferes with the normal operation of that institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital, provided that conspicuous signs are displayed in those streets indicating a school, hospital, or court street. 
(11)  Hawkers, peddlers and vendors. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers, and vendors which disturb the peace and quiet of any reasonable person in the neighborhood. 
(12)  Noises to attract attention. The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance, show or sale by creation of noise. 
(13)  Pile drivers, hammers, similar equipment. The operation any day between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which is attended by unreasonably loud sounds or noises. 
(14)  Blowers. The operation of any noise-creating blower, vacuum or power fan any day between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., the operation which causes unreasonable noise. 
(15)  Sound trucks. The use of mechanical loudspeakers or amplifiers on trucks or other moving or standing vehicles for advertising or other commercial purposes or when used at such an unreasonably loud volume so as to unreasonably disturb a reasonable person in his or her residence, offices, schools, hospitals, churches or courts; or for noncommercial purposes when used any day between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(16)  Aircraft. Noises associated with the takeoffs and landings of aircraft unless such takeoffs and landings take place on an authorized airport or other landing field, heliport or helipad located within a properly zoned district and in accordance with other applicable provisions of the Clayton County Code of Ordinances. 
(17)  Vehicles and loudspeakers. Noises associated with (i) the parking, loading, and unloading of trucks and other vehicles, and (ii) the use of mechanical loudspeakers or amplifiers emanating outside of buildings when such noises are unreasonably loud so as to disturb a reasonable person in his or her residence any day between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 01-41, § 1, 4-17-01) 
Sec. 62-3.4. - Exceptions. 
Loud, disturbing, and unnecessary noises do not include noise or sound generated by the following: 
(1)  Cries for emergency assistance and warning calls. 
(2)  Radios, sirens, horns and bells on any emergency response vehicle. 
(3)  Parades, fireworks displays, concerts and other special events for which a permit has been obtained from the county, within such hours and sound level limits as may be imposed as a condition for the issuance of the permit. Clayton County reserves the right to set limits on sound levels as well as the duration of sounds emanating from these activities. 
(4)  Activities on or in county and school athletic facilities and on or in publicly owned property and facilities, provided that such activities have been authorized by the owner of such property or facilities or its agent. Provided further that this exception for activities on or in county facilities or on or in county owned property and facilities shall not apply where the noise level for the activity measures 110 decibels or more between the hours of 8:01 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. or where the noise level for the activity measures 110 decibels or more between the hours of 9:01 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. In all cases the measurement shall be taken at the point of origin of the noise and with an instrument approved for such measurement by the director of parks and recreation. The first reading in violation of this part shall cause a warning to be issued to the activity. Any subsequent reading in violation of this part taken after the required warning has been issued shall result in the immediate revocation of any permit or other permission issued by the county for the activity and the activity must immediately cease and all participants disperse from county property. Failure to comply with any provisions of this part shall be a misdemeanor punishable as provided for in Part II, Chapter 1 "General Provisions" Section 1-12 "General Penalty" of the Clayton County Code of Ordinances. Notwithstanding the language contained in the foregoing provision, nothing in this subparagraph is intended directly or indirectly reflect the prohibition of any sound emanating from any regularly scheduled programming event, service or activity as authorized by the department of parks and recreation. 
(5)  Fire alarms and burglar alarms, prior to the giving of notice and a reasonable opportunity for the owner or tenant in possession of the premises served by any such alarm to turn off the alarm. 
(6)  Religious worship activities, including but not limited to bells and organs, as long as such noise, because of its volume level, duration and character does not annoy, disturb, injure or endanger the comfort, health, peace or safety of a reasonable person of ordinary sensibilities. 
(7)  Locomotives and other railroad equipment. 
(8)  Aircraft-related noises associated with aircraft while in flight and while under the jurisdiction of the Federal Aviation Administration or the Department of Defense. Also, aircraft-related noises associated with the takeoffs and landings of aircraft with technical difficulties, in any kind of distress, under emergency orders of air traffic control, or being operated in accordance with a declaration of an emergency under federal air regulations. 
(9)  The operation of lawn mowers, edgers, trimmers and power driven hedge shears, and other domestic power-operated equipment when operated with a properly functioning muffler meeting manufacturer's standards, and when such operation is between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on weekdays and 10:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on weekends and holidays. 
(10)  Operation of water craft upon any watercourse, lake, river, or swamp which is operated in accordance with Georgia laws. 
(11)  Farm equipment, farm machinery or other noise consistent with a lawfully permitted use within an AG zoning classification; however, this exception shall not apply to animal noise within 500 feet of a residential zoned district. 
(12)  Noise created in the ordinary course of existing lawfully permitted businesses in industrial zone classifications. 
(13)  The operation of two trucks while assisting motorists or towing disabled vehicles. 
(14)  Noises resulting from activities of a temporary duration, and for which a special permit has been granted pursuant to this Code section, and which conforms to the conditions and limitations stated thereon. Clayton County reserves the right to set limits on sound levels as well as the duration of sounds emanating from these activities. Clayton County reserves the right to set limits on sound levels and well as the duration of sounds emanating from these activities. 
(Ord. No. 01-41, § 1, 4-17-01; Ord. No. 2014-102, § 1, 5-6-14) 
Sec. 62-3.5. - Special permits. 
The director of community development is authorized to issue permits authorizing the conduct of activities otherwise prohibited by this Code section as follows: 
(1)  To persons who have applied in writing for such permits, on forms provided for this purpose, at least 21 days prior to the date for which such authorization is requested, and who have paid an administrative fee as established by the community development department at the time of submitting their applications. All permits issued shall state all conditions which, in the judgment of the director, are necessary to minimize the adverse impact of noise activities on residential or other noise-sensitive areas, including but not limited to naming an effective date, time of day, location and use of equipment permitted. In the case of construction activities, no such permit shall be valid for more than 45 consecutive days, provided that the director is further authorized to renew such permits upon subsequent applications accompanied by a showing that the grounds for issuance still exist. The director is authorized to issue such permits if the applicant has demonstrated to his or her satisfaction the following: 
a.  The activity, operation or noise source will be of a temporary duration, and cannot be conducted in compliance with the provisions of this Code section and no reasonable alternative is available; 
b.  The applicant requires additional time to alter or modify the activity to comply with the provisions of this Code section, and no reasonable alternative is available; or 
c.  The activity is being conducted for a public purpose by, or at the direction of, a governmental entity. 
(2)  To persons conducting activities in response to an emergency, when the circumstances constituting such emergency have been shown to his or her reasonable satisfaction, for a period of time which, in his or her judgment, is sufficient to remedy the emergency conditions. Such permits may be issued with an effective date retroactive to the initiation of the activity, and the administrative fee otherwise required may be waived. 
(Ord. No. 01-41, § 1, 4-17-01) 
Sec. 62-4. - Trespassing on posted construction sites. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Construction site includes both residential and commercial construction sites. The term does not include sites where additions or improvements are being made to an existing residential structure or where a garage, shed, etc., is being built adjacent to an existing residential structure. 
(b)  Prohibition. Anyone who, between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., or on a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday, knowingly and without authority, enters upon the premises of a construction site which is located within the unincorporated area of the county and which is posted with a notice sign "No Trespassing between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. or on weekends or holidays, by order of the Clayton County Police Department" shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(c)  Posting of signs. Before entry upon a construction site shall be a violation of this section, the person in rightful possession of the property or the builder, contractor, etc., must post the appropriate no trespassing sign at the construction site itself or in such a conspicuous manner as to give notice that the sign applies to an entire subdivision or commercial complex that is then under construction. 
(1)  Preparation of signs. The notice signs will be prepared by the county public works department and will contain the words: 
NO TRESPASSING 
BETWEEN THE HOURS OF 6 P.M. TO 6 A.M. OR ON WEEKENDS OR HOLIDAYS: BY ORDER OF THE CLAYTON COUNTY POLICE DEPARTMENT. 
No other signs will comply with the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Rental of signs. The developer, builder, contractor, etc., may rent no trespassing signs from the department of community development at the time the building permit is obtained. A cash deposit of $25.00 must be left with the department of community development for each sign rented. The deposit will be returned to the builder, developer, contractor, etc., after the sign has been returned to the department of community development. 
(d)  Persons to contact in reference to possible violations. The name and phone number of the person to contact in reference to a possible violation of this section shall either be posted along with the no trespassing sign or furnished to the county police department. 
(e)  Exemption of persons authorized to be on site. 
(1)  The property owner, contractor, etc., shall either furnish the county police department a list of the persons authorized to be on the construction site during the posted hours, post a list of the authorized persons at the site, or furnish the authorized persons with an identification card or other written permission to be on the site during the posted hours. 
(2)  Duly authorized real estate agents or brokers who possess proper identification, along with their prospective purchasers, who are on the construction site on official business, are not required to have an identification card or written permission to be on the construction site. 
(f)  Violation and penalty. For the violation of any of the provisions of this section, upon conviction, the person committing such violation shall be punished in accordance with section 1-12. 
(Code 1973, § 2-19-9) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
Sec. 62-5. - Discharge of weapons.
